[[Image:Lobby 7 hack in progress.jpg|thumb|300px|A hack in progress in Lobby 7.]]
'''Hacks''' at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] are [[practical joke]]s and [[student prank|pranks]] meant to prominently demonstrate technical aptitude and cleverness, or to commemorate popular culture and historical topics.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Boston Globe |date=April 1, 2003 |department=C |title=These Are Not Your Ordinary College Pranks}}</ref><ref name="MH">{{cite news|publisher=The Miami Herald |date=April 10, 2002 |department=4E Living |title=Elaborate Practice Jokes Make the Grade at MIT}}</ref><ref name="DMN">{{cite news|title= Scholarly MIT celebrates its crazier side |date=April 29, 1991 |publisher=Dallas Morning News}}</ref><ref name="Hacks and Smoots">{{cite news|title=Of Hacks and Smoot: MIT Students Have Engineered Campus Pranks since 1876 |publisher=Boston Globe |last=Gaine |first=Judith |date=April 1, 1991}}</ref><ref name="CT">{{cite news|title=MIT students exhibit ingenuity, humor |department=C |date=May 16, 1991 |last=Abell |first=John |publisher=Chicago Tribune}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/01/technology/screen-grab-fun-for-pranksters.html?scp=1&sq=mit+hack&st=nyt |title=Fun for Pranksters |publisher=The New York Times |first=Sreenath |last=Sreenivasan |date=April 1, 1999}}</ref> The pranks are anonymously installed at night by '''hackers''', usually, but not exclusively, undergraduate students. The actions of hackers are governed by an extensive and informal body of precedent, tradition, and ethics.<ref name=HackerEthicsBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=6|chapter=Hack, hacker, hacking; Hacking ethics}}</ref><ref name=HackerEthicsWeb>{{cite web|title=The "Hacker Ethic" [concise version]|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/misc/ethics.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref> Hacks can occur anywhere across campus, or occasionally off campus; many make use of the iconic [[Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology#Building 10|Great Dome]],<ref name=GreatDomeHacksWeb>{{cite web|title=Hacks on the Great Dome (Bldg. 10)|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_location/great_dome.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=DomeHacksBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=50–73|chapter=Domework: hacking the domes}}</ref> [[Infinite Corridor#Lobby 7|Little Dome]],<ref name=LittleDomeHacks>{{cite web|title=Hacks on the Small Dome (Bldg. 7)|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_location/small_dome.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref> [[Green Building (MIT)|Green Building]] tower,<ref name=GreenHacksWeb>{{cite web|title=Hacks on The Green Building (54)|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_location/54.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=GreenHacksBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=76–83|chapter=Greener pastures: the Green Building hacks}}</ref> or other prominent architectural features<ref name=ArchitHacksBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=112–119|chapter=Form + Function = Hack: the architectural hacks}}</ref> of the [[Campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT campus]]. Well-known hacker alumni include Nobel Laureates [[Richard Feynman|Richard P. Feynman]]<ref name=Feynman>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=41|quote=A Nobel-winning physicist, Feynman was equally famous for his practical jokes}}</ref> and [[George Smoot|George F. Smoot]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2006/10/04/at_mit_future_nobelist_not_above_a_prank_or_two/ |title=At MIT, future Nobelist not above a prank or two |publisher=Boston Globe |date=October 4, 2006 |last=Gil |first=Gideon}}</ref> In October 2009, US President [[Barack Obama]] made a humorous reference to the MIT hacking tradition during an on-campus speech about [[clean energy]].<ref name=HackObamaBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=13|chapter=Hacking into the new millennium|quote=I'll probably be here for awhile; I understand a bunch of engineering students put my motorcade on top of Building 10}}</ref>
Although the practice is unsanctioned by the university, and students have sometimes been arraigned on trespassing charges for hacking,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/1031/p02s03-ussc.html |title=Campus pranks now come with permission slips |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |first=Tom |last=Peter |date=October 31, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Prosecutors drop charges again 3 MIT students in prank case |date=February 28, 2007 |first=John |last=Ellement |publisher=Boston Globe}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hackers skirt security in late-night MIT treks |publisher=Boston Globe |date=March 30, 2000 |last=Abel |first=David}}</ref> hacks have substantial significance to MIT's history and student culture. Student bloggers working for the MIT Admissions Office have often written about MIT hacks, including those occurring during Campus Preview Weekend (CPW), an event welcoming admitted prospective freshman students.<ref name=AdmissionsBlog>{{cite web|title=CPW 2008: The Hack Edition|url=http://www.mitadmissions.org/topics/life/hacks_traditions/cpw_2008_the_hack_edition.shtml|website=Explore & discover MIT: Blogs|publisher=MIT Admissions Office|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> Alumni bloggers on the MIT Alumni Association website also report and document some of the more memorable hacks.<ref name=MITAA-Hacks>{{cite web|title=Entries tagged with "hacks"|url=http://alum.mit.edu/pages/sliceofmit/tag/hacks/|website=Slice of MIT: News & Views for the Alumni Community|publisher=MIT Alumni Association|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> Since the mid-1970s, the student-written guide ''How To Get Around MIT (HowToGAMIT)'' has included a chapter on hacking, and discusses history, hacker groups, ethics, safety tips, and risks of the activity.<ref name=HTG>{{cite book|title=How To Get Around MIT (HowToGAMIT)|year=2010–2011|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-9760779-6-1|pages=150–156|edition=39th|chapter=Hacking}}</ref>
For a decade, the [[MIT Museum]] included a "Hall of Hacks" featuring famous MIT hacks, but the section was closed in 2001,<ref name=HallHacks>{{cite web|last=Arnaout|first=Rima|title=Museum's Hall of Hacks Concludes Ten-Year Run|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V121/N10/10hacks.10n.html|website=The Tech|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> temporarily returning for a 2003 exhibition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/education/higher/articles/2003/08/24/at_mit_how_the_hack_they_did_it/ |title=At MIT, how the hack they did it |last=Hurley |first=Mary |publisher=Boston Globe |date=August 24, 2003}}</ref> In 2011, the display space was reallocated to the ''MIT 150'' exhibition, a year-long show commemorating MIT's 150th anniversary.<ref name=MIT150>{{cite web|title=MIT 150: 150 ideas, inventions, and innovators that helped shape our world|url=http://www.boston.com/news/education/higher/specials/mit150/|website=boston.com|publisher=The Boston Globe|accessdate=2012-04-07}}</ref> Although hacks were not featured in the exhibit, certain student activities such as the [[Traditions and student activities at MIT#Baker House Piano Drop|Annual Baker House Piano Drop]] were featured in the exhibition.<ref name=MIT150Hacks>{{cite web|title=Hackers' delight -- A history of MIT pranks|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/gallery/100308_mit_hacks/|website=boston.com|publisher=The Boston Globe|accessdate=2012-04-07}}</ref> The Museum's extensive collection of hacker artifacts and documentation continues to be preserved and expanded, with a selection of larger relics from past hacks plus explanatory panels and plaques semi-permanently displayed inside the [[Ray and Maria Stata Center|Stata Center]]. This mini-exhibit on hacks is located on the ground floor of the Stata Center, near the cafeteria at the southeastern end of the complex, and may be viewed by visitors during normal office hours.<ref name=StataHacks>[https://archive.is/20121212181253/http://alum.mit.edu/sliceofmit/2009/03/25/stata-look-and-feel/ Stata Look and Feel « Slice of MIT by the Alumni Association]. Alum.mit.edu (2009-03-25). Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref>
Famous hacks include a weather balloon labeled "MIT" appearing at the 50-yard line at the [[Harvard–Yale football rivalry|Harvard/Yale football game]] in 1982, the placing of a campus police cruiser on the roof of the Great Dome,<ref>{{cite news|title=MIT answers the siren call of a good joke |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date=May 10, 1994}}</ref> converting the Great Dome into [[R2-D2]] or a large yellow ring to acknowledge the release of ''[[Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace|Star Wars Episode I]]'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring|Lord of the Rings]]'' respectively,<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Boston Globe |last=Abel |first=David |date=May 23, 2001 |title=Weight of finals explains MIT prank: 'Hack' on dome gets high grade}}</ref> or placing full-sized replicas of the [[Wright Flyer]] and a fire truck to acknowledge the anniversaries of first powered controlled flight and the [[September 11 attacks|September 11th attacks]] respectively.<ref name="Firetruck">{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2006/09/mit_hacks_mark_1.html |title=MIT 'hacks' mark Sept. 11 with a fake fire truck |date=September 11, 2006 |publisher=Boston Globe}}</ref>
==Terminology== [[Image:MIT Simmons Smiles.jpg|thumb|300px|Residents of MIT's Simmons Hall collaborated to make a smiley face on the building's facade, December 8, 2002.]] {{See also|Hacker (term)}} At MIT, the terms ''hack'' and ''hacker'' have many shades of meaning,<ref name=JargonFile>{{cite web|last=Raymond|first=Eric|title=The Meaning of 'Hack'|url=http://www.catb.org/jargon/html/meaning-of-hack.html|website=The Jargon File (version 4.4.7)|accessdate=2011-05-03|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=HHH>{{cite web|last=Williams|first=Sam|title=Hack, Hackers, and Hacking|url=http://www.faifzilla.org/appendixb.html|website=FAIFzilla.org [website]|publisher=Sam Williams|accessdate=2011-05-17}}</ref><ref name=HackDefinitionBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=5–6|chapter=Hack, hacker, hacking; A short history of the terminology}}</ref> though they are closely linked historically and culturally with [[Hacker (term)|computer hacking]] (in its original non-[[Hacker (computer security)|computer-cracker]] sense), collegiate [[practical joke]]s, and even [[culture jamming]]. The origin of this usage is unknown, but it seems to have been widespread at MIT by the 1960s, and the [[hacker ethic]] has since spread into [[cyberculture]] and beyond. Over time, the term has been generalized to describe anybody who possesses great technical proficiency in any particular skill, usually combined with an offbeat sense of humor. The manifestation of hacker culture in the form of spectacular pranks is the most visible aspect of this culture to the world at large, but many hacker subcultures exist at MIT, and elsewhere. This article focuses mostly on prankish aspects; for a fuller description of hacker culture, see "[[Hacker (term)]]".
[[Roof and tunnel hacking]], a form of [[urban exploration]], is also related to but not identical to "hacking" as described in this article. Some hacks do involve overcoming barriers to physical access (e.g. placing a half-scale [[Apollo Lunar Module]] atop the Great Dome),<ref name=ApolloHack>{{cite web|title=Apollo Lunar Module on the Great Dome|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2009/apollo_lander/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-12}}</ref> but many other stunts do not require such specialized skills.
==Cultural aspects== Viewed from an [[anthropology|anthropological]] perspective, hacking is a cultural tradition affirming [[social cohesion|group solidarity]], but some hacks can also be viewed as individualistic creative or [[artistic expression]]. For example the "Massachusetts Toolpike" hack<ref name=Tech11040>{{cite web|last=Mehta|first=Prabhat|title=Journal of IHTFP a joyful account of MIT hacks|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V110/N40/hacks.40a.html|website=The Tech|accessdate=2011-04-22}}</ref> was a clear instance of [[installation art]]<ref name=GnomeInfestationWeb>{{cite web|title=Gnome Infestation|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2003/gnomes/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref><ref name=KeypadArtWeb>{{cite web|title=Cluster keypad artwork|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2003/keypad_art/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref> or [[environmental art]].<ref name=RockGardenHackWeb>{{cite web|title=Squanch Rock Garden in 2-4-6 Courtyard|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2000/tetazoo_garden/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref> Hacks which involve staged public actions<ref name=BOYD>{{cite web|title=Bring out your Dead|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1996/dead/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref><ref name=PerfHackWeb>{{cite web|title=Performance Hacks|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_topic/performance.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=PerfHackBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=166–169|chapter="Please wait to be served": the performance hacks}}</ref> (e.g. a [[Zombie walk|zombie march]] or the [[Time Traveler Convention]] of 2005) are clearly a form of [[performance art]], often combined with [[body art]] and [[cosplay]].<ref name=Pourian-Cosplay>{{cite news|last=Pourian|first=Jessica J.|title=Time to pretend: The Tech takes an inside look at cosplaying at MIT — how students take their engineering skills and apply them to crafting the perfect costume|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V133/N26/cosplay.html|accessdate=2013-05-14|newspaper=The Tech|date=May 14, 2013}}</ref> Still other hacks have a strong [[conceptual art]] flavor, often satirizing other purported works of conceptual art.<ref name=NestPas>{{cite web|title=Ceci n'est pas un hack|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2000/not_hack/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-26}}</ref><ref name=HairballHack>{{cite web|title=Slide Rule and the Student Center Hairball|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1990/slide_rule/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=HackGreatWindWeb>{{cite web|title=The Great Wind|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1996/great_wind/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-26}}</ref> Sometimes the boundaries have been deliberately blurred, for example when a satirical work of "conceptual art" (''No Knife: a study in mixed media earth tones, number three'') was surreptitiously added to a "serious" art gallery show at the [[List Visual Arts Center]].<ref name=TechKeyser>{{cite web|last=Chung|first=Jennifer|title=Keyser Discusses Hacks, Culture at TBP Lecture|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V118/N3/ctbp.3n.html|website=The Tech|accessdate=2011-04-22}}</ref><ref name=NoKnifeBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=106|chapter="All Mondays should be so beautiful": the art of hacking art}}</ref>
"Tribute", "memorial", or "commemorative" hacks note the arrival, passing, or anniversary of some noteworthy person, tradition, institution, or idea (e.g. the 10th anniversary of Wikipedia).<ref name=Wiki10th>{{cite web|title=Wikipedia 10th Anniversary|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2011/wikipedia/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-24}}</ref> Another broad category of hacks contains strong elements of [[social commentary]] or [[demonstration (people)|street protest]] (e.g. "Nth Annual Spontaneous Tuition Riot"<ref name=TechTuition>{{cite web|last=Chung|first=Jennifer|title=Students Protest Tuition Hike During Traditional Annual Riot|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V119/PDF/N12.pdf|website=The Tech|accessdate=2011-04-24}}</ref>) about events on campus or in the world at large. But the strongest element of many hacks is the sheer joy of conceptualizing something new, and then reifying it with effective engineering, both technical and social (e.g. installing a full-sized mockup solar-powered subway car on the parapet wall around the base of the Great Dome, and then ''driving it back and forth under remote wireless control'' from Killian Court, some five stories below, ''after sundown'').<ref name=SolarSubwayWeb>{{cite web|title=Solar Powered Subway Car on the Great Dome|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2009/solar_powered_subway/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-24}}</ref><ref name=SolarSubwayBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T.F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=13, 18–19}}</ref>
[[File:Wile E. Coyote's ACME Instant Tunnel at MIT.jpg|thumb|A mural of [[Wile E. Coyote and The Road Runner|Wile E. Coyote]] smashed into the wall of the Rotch Library.<ref name=Coyote/>]] Like most art exhibitions, the great majority of hacks are temporary installations; most are removed within a day or so by MIT Physical Plant, the MIT Confined Space Rescue Team (CSRT),<ref name=HackCSRTBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=192–195|chapter=Zen and the art of hacking; It's not a job, it's an adventure}}</ref> or occasionally by the hackers themselves. It is a traditional courtesy to leave a note or even engineering drawings behind, as an aid to safe de-installation of a hack.<ref name="HackCSRTBook"/> Sometimes, the hacks have been de-installed so quickly that members of the MIT community and the general public have had little opportunity to view them. On very rare occasions, community protests have caused the MIT administration to quietly allow a hack to be re-installed and left for a proper viewing interval.<ref name=Kilroy>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=54|chapter=Domework: hacking the domes; Dome as dais; Kilroy (aka George) was here, 1972}}</ref> The results of certain hacks (often wall murals<ref name=Coyote>{{cite web|title=Wile E. Coyote smashes into Rotch Library Wall|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1998/coyote/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=HackStargateWeb>{{cite web|title=Stargate in E19|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2008/stargate/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-27}}</ref>) have been considered "permanent improvements" to the campus environment, and have been left in place indefinitely, most notably the "[[Smoot]] marks" on the [[Harvard Bridge]]. The [[MIT Museum]] maintains an extensive collection of original hacker artifacts and documentation, and displays some larger items semi-permanently in the [[Ray and Maria Stata Center|Stata Center]].<ref name="StataHacks"/>
Although many traditional college pranks have involved maximizing embarrassment or inconvenience for a victim or target, such antics are usually disparaged by MIT hackers as "unimaginative" or "boring". Often the target of a hack is an abstract concept (e.g. [[bureaucracy]] or "[[political correctness]]", or [[entropy]]), and the prank may or may not be aimed at any specific individual. Even when an individual is targeted (e.g. the "disappearing office"<ref name=VestOffice>{{cite web|title=The Disappearing President's Office (The Bulletin Board Hack)|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1990/vest_bboard/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-25}}</ref><ref name=TechVest>{{cite web|title=Moving the Institute forward into the next century, Charles Vest thinks globally|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V110/N43/vest.43n.html|website=The Tech|accessdate=2011-04-25}}</ref> of newly arrived MIT President [[Charles Marstiller Vest|Charles Vest]]), the jest is good-natured, often eliciting admiration rather than anger from the "victim".
Writers for the third-party, independent Internet prankster site ''Zug'' once compared humorous responses at MIT and Harvard, by posting similar banners over main entrances to their respective campuses which proclaimed "Institute of Nowlege". Regarding Harvard, they concluded, "The question: is the sense of humor still alive in modern-day Harvard students? The answer, it turns out, is ''no''." Regarding MIT, they said, "So it's official: MIT students have a better sense of humor, hands down, than Harvard students. MIT students are more imaginative, more fun-loving, and probably smarter as well. Truly, MIT is the Institute of NOWLEGE." The ''Zug'' pranksters also noted and documented great differences in the reactions of [[campus police]], maintenance workers, and passersby, upon seeing the ironically [[pun]]ned banners.<ref name=ZugHarvardMIT>{{cite web|last=Hargrave |first=John |title=Harvard vs. MIT: Who Has the Better Sense of Humor? |url=http://www.zug.com/pranks/harvard-vs-mit/index.html |website=Zug: Prank You Very Much |publisher=Media Shower, Inc. |accessdate=2011-05-12 |author2=Mike Hoban |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104202203/http://www.zug.com/pranks/harvard-vs-mit/index.html |archivedate=January 4, 2011 }}</ref>
MIT hacks can push the limits of technical skill, and sometimes fail in spite of meticulous planning. Even these engineering failures have been acknowledged to have educational value, and sometimes a follow-up attempt succeeds. One hack on the Great Dome is documented as having finally succeeded on the fourth try, after a complete re-engineering of both the installed artifact and the installation method.<ref name=HackNippleBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=56–57|chapter=Domework: hacking the domes; Dome as dais; The great breast of knowledge, 1979}}</ref>
Smaller projects that can be completed by an individual student are sometimes accorded the honorific "a great hack" by other students, if they combine technical elegance with a hackish sense of humor. For example, an MIT undergrad transformed an ordinary grocery [[shopping cart]] into a high-performance [[electric vehicle]], and had been frequently seen riding around campus in his "LOLrioKart".<ref name=GizmodoKart>{{cite web|last=Frucci|first=Adam|title=MIT Students Build a Speedy Go-Kart Out of a Shopping Cart|url=https://gizmodo.com/5303616/mit-students-build-a-speedy-go+kart-out-of-a-shopping-cart|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> The shopping cart had a claimed top speed over {{convert|45|mph}}, and also had a complex steering wheel linkage and a low [[Steering|turning radius]] for maneuverability in tight spaces. The student was a strong advocate of the [[open-source hardware|Open Source Hardware]] philosophy, and incorporated detailed documentation of his projects and a tutorial on building custom [[wheel hub motor]]s in his blog.<ref name=GuanBlog>{{cite web|last=Guan|first=Charles Z|title=[Homepage]|url=http://www.etotheipiplusone.net/|website=Equals zero|publisher=etotheipiplusone.net|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> The ersatz vehicle was prominently displayed at many MIT events, as well as at the [[Cambridge Science Festival]]. As a crowning mark of recognition by the outside world, the LOLrioKart driver once received a traffic ticket from the Cambridge Police, a copy of which was proudly displayed online.<ref name=TrafficTicket>{{cite web|last=Guan|first=Charles Z|title=I Love Cambridge|url=http://miters.mit.edu/2009/08/30/i-love-cambridge/|website=MITERS [Blog]|publisher=MIT Electronic Research Society (MITERS)|accessdate=2011-05-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225093506/http://miters.mit.edu/2009/08/30/i-love-cambridge/|archivedate=2011-02-25|df=}}</ref>
Some of the best large-scale hacks (e.g. the Caltech cannon heist) have involved multiple teams of hackers working on coordinated but diverse subtasks such as fund-raising, "[[Social engineering (security)|social engineering]]", [[Rigger (industry)|rigging]], [[logistics|transportation logistics]], [[electroplating|gold electroplating]], and precision [[numerical control|numerical controlled machining]], calling on a wide range of technical and management skills.<ref name=CalCannon>{{cite web|title=Caltech's Fleming Cannon transported to MIT|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2006/mitcannon/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-28}}</ref> Not surprisingly, some hacker teams have gone on to found start-up business ventures, though they may be reluctant to reveal their earlier exploits until many years have passed.{{citation needed|date= April 2011}}
==Famous hacks== One classic hack involved a police car with its flashing warning lights operating. The unusual aspect of this hack was its position — on top of MIT's Great Dome. The car was found to be a gutted, junked, heavy Chevrolet, painted meticulously to match the MIT Campus Police patrol cars. The car's number was [[pi]]. Its license plate read "[[#IHTFP|IHTFP]]", the abbreviation for MIT's unofficial slogan. A dummy dressed as a campus patrolman was seated inside with mug of coffee and a box of donuts.<ref name=CP-Car>{{cite web|title=CP Car on the Great Dome|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1994/cp_car/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref> Some years later, the police car has now been semi-permanently re-installed in the [[Ray and Maria Stata Center|Stata Center]] as an all-time classic.<ref name="StataHacks"/>
Due to MIT's proximity to Harvard, many hacks involve the annual [[Harvard–Yale football rivalry|Harvard-Yale]] [[American football|football]] game. Because of the Cambridge rivalry between MIT and Harvard, hackers often are found at the games, and they have come up with some of the most famous hacks in the Institute's history.<ref name=HackHarvardWeb>{{cite web|title=Hacks on Harvard|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_topic/harvard.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref name=HackHarvardBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=170–183|chapter=When MIT won the Harvard-Yale game: hacking Harvard}}</ref>
One such notable hack attempt targeting the 1948 Harvard-Yale football game<ref name=HackHarvardBook1948>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|page=172|chapter=When MIT won the Harvard-Yale game: hacking Harvard}}</ref> involved the use of [[detonating cord|primer cord]]. One night shortly before the game MIT students snuck into the Harvard stadium and buried primer cord just under the field. The plan was to burn the letters MIT into the middle of the field during the game. However, their work was uncovered by groundskeepers and disabled. During the game the hackers were apprehended while wearing heavy coats on a fair-weather day. The coats were lined with batteries, obviously intended to be used to detonate the primer cord. An apocryphal story is that an MIT dean came to their defense, opening his own battery-lined coat and claiming that "all Tech men carry batteries"; an MIT dean did show up, but he was not wearing batteries. This phrase has since become common among MIT students.
The Harvard-Yale football game was again the target of MIT hackers in 1982<ref name=HackHarvardBook1982>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=172–176|chapter=When MIT won the Harvard-Yale game: hacking Harvard}}</ref> when a large weather balloon painted with "MIT" all around was inflated, seemingly from nowhere, in the middle of the field. The next day the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' ran the headline "MIT 1—Harvard-Yale 0: Tech Pranksters Steal the Show". The 1982 Harvard-Yale hack earned acclaim as winner of "Hack Madness", a [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|March Madness]]-themed contest sponsored by the MIT Alumni Association in 2014 to determine "the greatest MIT hack of all time".<ref name=HackMadness>{{cite web|title=The Harvard-Yale Football Game is MIT Hack Madness Champion|url=https://alum.mit.edu/pages/sliceofmit/2014/03/14/hack-champion/|year=2014|publisher=Slice of MIT|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts}}</ref>
In 1990 an MIT banner was successfully launched from an end zone using a model rocket engine shortly before Yale attempted a field goal kick.<ref name=HarvardYale1990>{{cite web|title=Harvard-Yale Game Banner|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1990/H-Y/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref> In 1996, the Harvard logos on the scoreboard were hacked from ''VE-RI-TAS'' to read ''HU-GE-EGO'' instead.<ref name=HY-Ego>{{cite web|title="Huge Ego" at Harvard-Yale game|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2006/H_Y_huge_ego/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref>
Another traditional hacking target has been the bronze [[John Harvard (statue)|statue of John Harvard]],<ref name=HackJohnHarvardBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=181–183|chapter=When MIT won the Harvard-Yale game: hacking Harvard}}</ref> the namesake of [[Harvard University]]. The statue itself was sculpted by [[Daniel Chester French]], a respected artist who studied at MIT, who is best known for his statue of ''[[Abraham Lincoln (1920 statue)|Abraham Lincoln]]'' at the [[Lincoln Memorial]] in [[Washington DC]]. Because of its visible location in [[Harvard Yard]] and its symbolic significance, the John Harvard statue has been fitted with an unending sequence of "[[fashion accessory|accessories]]". MIT hackers are hardly alone; [[Dartmouth College]] pranksters like to paint the statue green, [[Yale]] pranksters prefer blue, and others have dressed the statue in women's underwear. MIT hackers like to go a few steps further, fitting the statue with a plaster leg cast after a crushing football defeat,<ref name=HarvardCast>{{cite web|title=Cast on John Harvard|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1990/harvard_cast/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> and disguising the statue as the [[Unabomber]] after that infamous Harvard alumnus was arrested.<ref name=UnabomberHack>{{cite web|title=Unabomber Suspect Apprehended in Harvard Yard|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1996/unabomber/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> John Harvard has worn a [[Brass Rat]] from time to time, and has donned a Halo combat helmet and brandished a Halo assault rifle to mark the release of the ''Halo 3'' [[first-person shooter]] video game.<ref name=HarvardHalo3>{{cite web|title=John Harvard plays Halo3|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2007/halo3_john_harvard/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> In accordance with hacker ethics, great care is taken to ensure that the hacks can be removed without causing permanent damage to Harvard's treasured symbol.<ref name=HackJohnHarvardRingBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=181–182|chapter=When MIT won the Harvard-Yale game: hacking Harvard}}</ref>
The cleverness of many MIT hacks has even resulted in [[urban legend]]s about supposed hacks that may not have occurred. One rumored hack involved a certain student's adherence to [[classical conditioning]] behavior response, as studied by Harvard Professor [[B. F. Skinner]]. Throughout the off-season, this supposed student visited the Harvard football stadium during his lunch break. He dressed in a black and white striped shirt and trousers, filled his pockets with bird-seed, then went on the field, blew a whistle, and spread his birdseed on the field. The result of all of this effort, the story goes, is that on opening day as the Harvard football team took the field to face their opponent, the referee blew his whistle to signal the start of the game, and the field was suddenly inundated by a flock of birds looking for their lunch. Despite sounding like a classic MIT hack, this particular prank has never been verified. The author of a 1990 book about pranks pulled by MIT students stated that he had not come across clear documentation of this tale during his years of research.<ref>[https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20081216214708/http://www.snopes.com/college/pranks/birdseed.asp Seeded Field Prank]. snopes.com. Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref>
On the other hand, at least one hack involved a staged event that never occurred, when hackers convinced major news media that they had created an indoor snowstorm in Baker House dormitory.<ref name=BakerSnow>{{cite web|title=The Great Baker House Snow Hack|url=http://museum.mit.edu/nom150/entries/1446|website=MIT 150 Exhibition Nominations|publisher=MIT Museum|accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
When MIT replaced older [[mercury-vapor lamp]]s with high-efficiency [[LED lamp]]s<ref>[http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/domelit-0612.html Great Dome lights up the night] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528203222/http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/domelit-0612.html |date=May 28, 2013 }}. Web.mit.edu (2007-06-12). Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref> to illuminate the Great Dome, hackers started changing the color<ref name="ericschmiedl.com">[http://www.ericschmiedl.com:80/hacks/index11.html Hacks and Pranks at MIT -Photography by Boston and Cambridge Editorial and Commercial Photographer Eric Schmiedl – Page 11]{{cbignore|bot=medic}}. Ericschmiedl.com. Retrieved on 2011-05-07.{{Dead link|date=September 2012}}</ref> of the lights to reflect various occasions — [[Earth Day]], the [[Independence Day (United States)|Fourth of July]], etc.<ref>[http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2007/purple_dome/ IHTFP Hack Gallery: Purple Dome] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160801051829/http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2007/purple_dome/ |date=August 1, 2016 }}. Hacks.mit.edu (2007-09-02). Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref><ref>[http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2007/redwhiteblue_dome/ IHTFP Hack Gallery: Red, White, and Blue Dome for Fourth of July] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160801054218/http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2007/redwhiteblue_dome/ |date=August 1, 2016 }}. Hacks.mit.edu (2007-07-04). Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref><ref>[http://hacks.mit.edu/by_year/2007/green_dome/ IHTFP Hack Gallery: Green Dome] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304133519/http://hacks.mit.edu/by_year/2007/green_dome/ |date=March 4, 2016 }}. Hacks.mit.edu (2007-06-20). Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref> Although reprogramming the lights is technically straightforward, these Great Dome lighting hacks are very visible from Boston's [[Back Bay, Boston|Back Bay]] district, across the [[Charles River]].
In September 2011, hackers installed 153 (= 9 x 17) custom-made wirelessly-controlled color-changing high-power [[LED]] lights into every window above the first floor of the 295-foot (90 m) tall MIT [[Green Building (MIT)|Green Building]]. They displayed a waving [[American flag]] throughout the evening of September 11, 2011 in remembrance of the [[September 11 attacks]] of 2001. For a short time in the early morning of September 12, the lights displayed a [[Tetris]] game, thus realizing a long-standing hack proposal, the "[[Holy Grail]]" of hacks. The display hardware had occasional glitches, and was removed as of September 13. The hardware and software designs were further developed and refined for better reliability. On April 20, 2012, MIT hackers successfully turned the Green Building into a huge playable Tetris game, operated from a wireless control podium at a comfortable viewing distance in front of the building. Visitors to Campus Preview Weekend (a gathering for admitted prospective freshman students) were invited to play the game on the colossal display grid (80 ft. wide x 250 ft. high), which was claimed to be the second-largest full-color video display in the US.<ref name=Pourian>{{cite news|last=Pourian|first=Jessica J.|title=The 'holy grail' of hacks: The construction of one of the most anticipated hacks of all time|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V132/N22/tetris.html|accessdate=2012-05-06|newspaper=The Tech|date=May 1, 2012}}</ref><ref name=Parker>{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Brock|title=Hackers convert MIT building in giant Tetris video game|url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/news/cambridge/2012/04/hackers_convert_mit_building_i.html|accessdate=2012-05-06|newspaper=Boston.com|date=April 24, 2012}}</ref><ref name=HackGalleryTetris>{{cite web|title=Tetris on the Green Building|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2012/tetris/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|publisher=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2012-05-06}}</ref>
Instead of a one-shot temporary installation, the hackers have designed and built a permanent facility that can be re-used repeatedly by the MIT community. An understanding has been reached with the EAPS Department, which is headquartered in the Green Building, to allow the light display hardware to remain installed in each window. To avoid annoying the occupants and to allow late-working staff to "opt out", each light display is equipped with a manual override button, which will disable the [[pixel]] lighting for that window for several hours after it is pressed. In addition, the hackers have released [[Open Source]] software tools used to develop new display patterns, so that others can design and deploy new stationary or animated images, in cooperation with the hacker engineers.<ref name="Pourian"/>
==IHTFP== '''IHTFP'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihtfp.com/ihtfp.html |title=What is IHTFP? |website=Ihtfp.com |accessdate=2012-04-23}}</ref> is an abbreviation which is part of the folklore at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. It originally stood for "I Hate This Fucking Place" but, due to use of profanity, is often [[euphemism|euphemized]] with other [[backronym]]s. Some of the more popular meanings include "I Have The Fucking Power" (Hacking), "I Help Tutor Freshman Physics", "It's Hard To Fondle Penguins", "I'm Hankering To Find Paradise", and "Interesting Hacks To Fascinate People", as well as "I Have Truly Found Paradise", "Institute for Hacks, TomFoolery, and Pranks" and "Institute Has The Finest Professors."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mit.edu/people/mjbauer/ihtfp.html |title=IHTFP |website=Mit.edu |accessdate=2012-04-23}}</ref> MIT leadership has even adapted the acronym, using it to encourage vaccination during the 2009–2010 flu season with a banner in the MIT medical building that read "I Hate This Flu Pandemic". The precise time of origin is unknown, though the term IHTFP was already widely used at MIT by 1960.
The letters "IHTFP" have been featured prominently on some hacks,<ref name=IHTFP-Hack>{{cite web|title=I Will Hate This F***ing Place|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2008/iwhtfp/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref><ref name=IHTFP-Balloons>{{cite web|title=IHTFP Balloons|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2003/ihtfp_balloons/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=IHTFP-GreatDome>{{cite web|title=MCMXVI changed to IHTFP on Great Dome|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1995/ihtfp_dome/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=IHTFP-Flag>{{cite web|title=I Hate The Flag Policy|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2004/flag_policy/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name=HackIHTFPBook>{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork : a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=74–75|chapter=Intriguing Hacks To Fascinate People}}</ref> but are more usually subtly embedded within other hacks as an inside joke. A very common motif in the MIT [[MIT class ring|Brass Rat]] (class ring) prior to 2013 was the inclusion of the letters "IHTFP" hidden somewhere within the frame of the bezel.
The 2016 celebrations of MIT's 'crossing of the Charles' in 1916, featured a translations as 'I Honor Theory (and) Forgo Practice'. This was part of a play / sketch addressing the friction between theoretical and applied researchers.
==Caltech rivalry== {{main|Caltech–MIT rivalry}}
MIT and [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]] have been prank rivals since Spring 2005, when a group of Caltech students traveled to Cambridge to pull a string of pranks during "Campus Preview Weekend" (CPW) for prospective new MIT students. The stunts included covering up the word "Massachusetts" in the "Massachusetts Institute of Technology" engraving on the main building façade with a banner, so that it read "That Other Institute of Technology". A group of MIT hackers quickly responded by altering the banner so that the inscription read "The Only Institute of Technology".<ref name=HackCaltechBook> {{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Institute Historian T. F.|title=Nightwork: a history of hacks and pranks at MIT (updated edition)|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51584-9|pages=8–13|chapter=Hacking into the new millennium}}</ref>
MIT students retaliated for CPW in April 2006, when students posing as the [http://www.howeandser.com/ "Howe & Ser Moving Co."] abducted the 130-year-old, 1.7 ton Fleming House Cannon and moved it to their campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, thus reprising a similar prank performed by [[Harvey Mudd College]] in 1986.<ref name=HackCaltechBook/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2006/04/19/comedy_on_campus_mit_takes_on_caltech_for_prank_distinction/ |title=Comedy on Campus: MIT takes on Caltech for prank distinction |date=April 19, 2006 |publisher=Boston Globe |first=Catherine |last=Elton}}</ref> To add a technical flourish, a [[Carat (purity)|24K]] gold-plated precisely upscaled machined replica of the famed [[Brass Rat]] (MIT's graduation ring) was tightly fitted over the barrel of the cannon, which was carefully aimed in the direction of Caltech.<ref name="CalCannon"/> Twenty-three members of Caltech Fleming House traveled to MIT to reclaim their cannon on April 10, 2006. They were greeted by a larger group of MIT students, who offered them a [[barbecue|BBQ]] farewell party. In exchange, the Caltech students offered a small toy cannon, saying that this was "more your size".
During MIT's CPW in 2007, Caltech distributed a complete fake edition of ''[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]'' (MIT's student newspaper) with the headline article reading "MIT Invents the Interweb". Another article announced the discovery, "Infinite Corridor Not Actually Infinite", referring to MIT's [[Infinite Corridor|iconic main thoroughfare]]. The edition included a mock weather forecast, referring often to how sunny [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] (where Caltech is located) is compared to [[Boston]], as well as other satirical articles.<ref name="HackCaltechBook"/>
In 2008, Caltech students provided a "Puzzle Zero" in the [[MIT Mystery Hunt]] which when solved, told solvers to "CALL 1-626-848-3780 ASAP". When MIT students dialed the number, they heard, "Thank you for calling the Caltech Admissions Office. If you are another MIT student wishing to transfer to Caltech, please download our transfer application form from www.caltech.edu. If you are an MIT student not wishing to transfer to Caltech, we wish you the best of luck, and hope you find happiness someday...."<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Harvey |title=Rub a dub dub, a suspect in a tub; Battle of the brains |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/columnists/la-me-only8-2008jun08,0,6914716.column |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tribune Company]] |date=2008-06-08 |accessdate=2008-07-12 }}</ref>
Around Thanksgiving weekend in 2009, yet another fake edition of ''The Tech'' was released, alleging that MIT had been sold to Caltech and would become "Caltech East: School of Humanities". Students would be required to take a core of literature, history, philosophy, and economics, but science subjects would be eliminated.<ref name="HackCaltechBook"/>
In the past few years, MIT hackers have tended to ignore Caltech "nuisance" pranks, instead preferring to perform more imaginatively engineered hacks on their own home campus. In particular, the majority of documented hacks occurring during CPW have been perpetrated by MIT students themselves.<ref name=CreativePeople>{{cite web|title="Creative People with Words" items appear around campus|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2009/creative_people_with_words/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref><ref name=Annual>{{cite web|title=Annual Event Hacks [CPW]|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_topic/timing-dependent.html|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> MIT hackers have only rarely interfered with Caltech traditions, rituals, or celebrations. But some MIT hackers do occasionally engage in low-level "sniping" back and forth with Caltech pranksters. For example, hackers made a website http://www.mitrejects.com redirect to Caltech's homepage. Caltech then did the same, with https://web.archive.org/web/20110614193503/http://www.caltechrejects.com/ redirecting to the MIT homepage.
A possible change in attitude started when a [[TARDIS]], which hackers had placed on the MIT Little Dome (August 25, 2010) and the MIT Great Dome (August 30, 2010), was transported to the roof of Baxter Hall at Caltech (January 4, 2011) by MIT and Caltech pranksters, where it remained for several weeks. The traveling time-machine subsequently reappeared atop Birge Hall at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] (January 29, 2011), and then rematerialized on the Durand Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering Building at [[Stanford University]] (March 18, 2011). The TARDIS came complete with a helpful note explaining how to disassemble it, and suggesting passing it on to other unexplored destinations.<ref name=MIT-TARDIS> {{cite web|last=IHTFP Gallery Advisory Board|title=TARDIS on building 7, great dome, and beyond |url = http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/2010/tardis/ |website=Interesting Hacks To Fascinate People: The MIT Gallery of Hacks|accessdate=2011-04-18}}</ref>
==Chronology of selected recent hacks== The MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery website<ref name=IHTFP-Gallery>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the IHTFP Gallery!|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-01}}</ref> has an extensive but far from complete catalog of past hacks related to MIT, including numerous documentary photos. More-complete coverage, especially of older hacks, appears in the books listed under [[#Further reading|Further Reading]] below, but these printed volumes appear only intermittently. The listing here only summarizes a few salient examples from MIT's long tradition of hacking.
===2017===
In the early morning of April 26, 2017, recent graduate Nicholas William Paggi died while hacking the Great Dome. According to the MIT newspaper, The Tech, the brilliant computer scientist slipped and fell to his death.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thetech.com/2017/04/27/nicholas-paggi |title=MIT graduate and 'brilliant programmer' dies on campus |accessdate=2017-12-28}}</ref>
===2013=== On the evening of January 10, 2013, [[Pac-Man]] and Blinky appeared on the scaffolding covering the Great Dome during reconstruction. According to the MIT alumni blog ''Slice of MIT'', the Pac-Man vs. Blinky battle was intended to serve as a metaphor for the semester. "Pac-Man represents the unquenchable search for knowledge, while Blinky represents the unforeseen distractions that may occur."<ref>{{cite news | first = Lauren | last = Landry | title = New Year, New Hack: MIT Students Place Pac-Man On Top of the Great Dome | date = January 11, 2013 | publisher = Streetwise Media | url = http://bostinno.com/2013/01/11/mit-pac-man-hack-to-the-great-dome-photos/#ss__283060_236262_0__ss | work = [[BostInno]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Lauren | last = Dezenski | title = In whimsical retro tribute, Pac-Man appears on MIT's Great Dome | date = January 11, 2013 | publisher = NY Times Co | url = http://www.boston.com/metrodesk/2013/01/11/mrs-pac-man-appears-mit-great-dome/T7qxv9hmVtJb6hJEauu7ZJ/story.html | work = [[Boston.com]] | accessdate = 2013-01-11}}</ref>
===2012=== Although it might not strictly be categorized as a hack, the [[MIT Gangnam Style]] parody video<ref name=MITGangnam>{{cite web|last=H.|first=Anna|title=MIT Gangnam Style|url=http://mitadmissions.org/blogs/entry/mit-gangnam-style|website=MIT Admissions|publisher=MIT|accessdate=2013-03-08}}</ref> released October 27, 2012, was a major student-run project that involved coordinating hundreds of people and over 25 different student organizations.<ref name=TechGangnam>{{cite news|last=Pourian|first=Jessica J.|title=MIT Gangnam Style: gone viral|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V132/N51/gangnam.html|accessdate=2013-03-08|newspaper=The Tech|date=November 6, 2012}}</ref> The music video closely follows the original version, and includes cameo appearances by MIT professors [[Donald Sadoway]], recognized by ''Time Magazine'' in 2012 as one of the "Top 100 Most Influential People in the World", [[Eric Lander]], who was co-chairman of President Barack Obama's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, and [[Noam Chomsky]], a pioneer of modern linguistics. The parody quickly reached #1 most popular video in Entertainment and #6 overall on YouTube, was called the "Best Gangnam Style Parody Yet" by ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/29/mit-chomsky-style-best-gagnam-style-parody-yet_n_2040053.html |title=MIT 'Chomsky Style' Best Gangnam Parody Yet? Noted Intellectual Steals The Wacky Show (VIDEO) |website=Huffington Post |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-11}}</ref> and got an enthusiastic reaction from [[Psy (entertainer)|Psy]], the star and producer of the original video.<ref>Retrieved from: {{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/scooterbraun/status/264810504323735553 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-03-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304230158/https://twitter.com/scooterbraun/status/264810504323735553 |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref>

===Previous hacks=== ;April 1, 1998: As an [[April Fools' Day|April Fool's Day]] prank, the MIT home page was replaced with a page announcing the university had been bought by [[The Walt Disney Company]] for [[United States dollar|$]]6.9 billion. The hacked page showed a picture of [[Mickey Mouse]] ears atop the Great Dome, and replaced the letter I in MIT with the lower-case "i" from Disney's [[wordmark]]. It even contained a fake press release with statements purportedly from Disney and MIT officials, detailing terms of the acquisition.<ref name=MITDisney>{{cite web|title=Is Disney buying MIT or was the MIT home page hacked?|url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1998/disney_buys_mit/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-04-28}}</ref> ;June 7, 1996: During a speech made by Vice-President [[Al Gore]] at the graduation ceremony, the graduates played [[Buzzword bingo]] using cards which had been distributed by hackers. The cards featured technical words which students believed were overused by people outside the technical professions, such as "[[information superhighway|Information Superhighway]]". Gore, who was informed of the hack, acknowledged it during his speech.<ref>[http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1996/gore/front_top.gif IHTFP Hacks Gallery: Al Gore Buzzword Bingo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908171413/http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1996/gore/front_top.gif |date=September 8, 2016 }}</ref> ;May 9, 1994: A carefully assembled outer frame of a car painted as an MIT Campus Police car appeared on top of the Great Dome. This hack quickly gained recognition on many local news sources and on national television.<ref name="CP-Car"/> ;December 9, 1991: It has been often said that "Getting an Education from MIT is like taking a drink from a Fire Hose", inspiring hackers to connect a real fire hose and a concrete-embedded [[fire hydrant]] to a drinking fountain in Building 16. Years later, the iconic monument has been semi-permanently re-installed by the MIT Museum in the [[Ray and Maria Stata Center|Stata Center]].<ref name=FireHoseHack>{{cite web|title=Fire Hose Drinking Fountain |url=http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1991/fire_hydrant/|website=MIT IHTFP Hack Gallery|accessdate=2011-05-02}}</ref> ;October 31, 1979: A lifesize fiberglass cow appeared on top of the Great Dome. The cow was later installed by the MIT Museum in the [[Ray and Maria Stata Center|Stata Center]]. ;November 1963: The first ever reference to malicious [[security hacker|hacking]] is '[[phreaking|telephone hackers]]' in MIT's student newspaper, ''The Tech'' of hackers trying up the lines with [[Harvard University|Harvard]], configuring the [[PDP-1]] to make free calls, [[war dialing]] and accumulating large phone bills.<ref>https://infostory.com/2011/11/20/hacking-and-blue-boxes/</ref><ref>http://duartes.org/gustavo/blog/post/first-recorded-usage-of-hacker/</ref><ref>http://tech.mit.edu/V83/PDF/V83-N24.pdf</ref> ;October 1958: [[Oliver R. Smoot]], a pledge of MIT's [[Lambda Chi Alpha]] fraternity in 1958, was used to measure the length of the [[Harvard Bridge]]. As he lay on the sidewalk of the bridge that carries Massachusetts Avenue across the [[Charles River]], markings were made at intervals corresponding to his height. The bridge was measured to be 364.4 [[Smoot]]s (plus or minus one ear) in length. During renovation of the bridge in 1964 the markings were carefully restored, and the markings remain to this day. ;1930s: Ken Wadleigh, who later in life became a dean at MIT, and 4 others welded a streetcar to metal rails by first distracting the [[motorman]] and then setting off [[thermite]] bombs to weld the wheels in place.<ref name=trolleyHack>{{cite web|title=Happy 60th Birthday to the Word "Hack"|url=http://slice.mit.edu/2015/04/06/happy-birthday-hack/|accessdate=2015-04-29}}</ref><ref name=trolleyHack1>{{cite web|title=From the Cathouse, an Editorial, by weasel, who isn't one|url=http://web.mit.edu/activities/voodoo/archive/pdfs/1968-Mar.pdf|website=Voodoo, Apr 1, 1968, p. 28|accessdate=2015-04-29}}</ref>

The '''Heritage Crafts Association''' (HCA) is a registered [[United Kingdom]] [[Charitable organization|charity]]<ref>{{EW charity|1159208|THE HERITAGE CRAFTS ASSOCIATION}}</ref> set up to support and promote traditional [[crafts]].
The charity was launched at the Victoria & Albert Museum in March 2010,<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/mar/22/heritage-crafts-at-risk</ref> with a membership programme for supporters.<ref>http://www.craftscotland.org/Default.aspx.LocID-cftnewkcp.RefLocID-cft04e001001.Lang-EN.htm</ref>
The HCA initiated a 30-minute adjournment debate on the state of traditional crafts in Westminster in June 2009.<ref>https://www.theyworkforyou.com/debates/?id=2009-06-25c.1036.0</ref>
In May 2017, in association with [[Radcliffe Trust|The Radcliffe Trust]], the Association published the [[HCA Red List of Endangered Crafts]].<ref >{{Cite web |title=The Radcliffe Red List of Endangered Crafts |publisher=Heritage Crafts Association / [[Radcliffe Trust]] |url=http://heritagecrafts.org.uk/redlist/list-of-crafts/ }}</ref> This publication was also covered on [[Woman's Hour]].<ref >{{Cite episode |title=Endangered Crafts |series=Woman's Hour |network=[[BBC Radio 4]] |date=4 May 2017 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08njv62#play }}</ref>
The HCA holds the secretariat of the [[All-party parliamentary group|All Party Parliamentary Group]] on Craft, which first met on 16 October 2018 and is chaired by the [[John Hayes (British politician)|Rt Hon John Hayes MP]].
== Trustees and patrons == The President of the Heritage Crafts Association is HRH [[Prince of Wales]] and it is run by a board of trustees, including professional [[scribe]] [[Patricia Lovett]] (chair), Richard Hobbs (vice-chair) and Robin Wood (professional wood turner and co-founder of Spoonfest with [[Barn the Spoon]]).<ref name="hca2018">{{cite web|title=Who we are|url=http://heritagecrafts.org.uk/who-we-are/|website=The Heritage Crafts Association|accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref>
Other patrons include: *[[Lord Cormack]] – Conservative Peer *[[Sir Christopher Frayling]] – Rector at [[Royal College of Art]] (1996-2009) *[[Emma Bridgewater]] – ceramics manufacturer *[[Kaffe Fassett]] – textile designer *Mark Henderson – Chairman of [[Gieves & Hawkes|Gieves and Hawkes]], No. 1 Savile Row *[[Alex Langlands]] – archaeologist and star of ''[[Victorian Farm]]'' and ''[[Tales from the Green Valley]]'' *Professor May Cassar - Professor of Sustainable Heritage at [[University College London]]

{{advert|date=December 2012}} '''Hit Song Science''' is a term coined by [[Mike McCready (music entrepreneur)|Mike McCready]] and trademarked by the company he co-founded, [[Polyphonic HMI]]. It concerns the possibility of predicting whether a song will be a hit, prior to its distribution using automated means such as [[machine learning]] software.
==Scientific background== The scientific nature of Hit Song Science is a subject of debate in the [[music information retrieval]] (MIR) community. Early studies claimed that using [[machine learning]] techniques could capture some information from audio signals and lyrics that would explain<ref>Dhanaraj, R. and Logan, B. Automatic Prediction of Hit Songs, Proc. of Ismir 2005, London, UK</ref> popularity. However, a larger-scale evaluation<ref>Pachet, F. and Roy, P. (2008) [http://www.csl.sony.fr/downloads/papers/2008/pachet-08c.pdf Hit Song Science is Not Yet a Science]. Proceedings of Ismir 2008, pages 355-360, Philadelphia, USA</ref> contradicts the claims of “Hit Song Science”, i.e. that the popularity of a music title can be learned effectively from known audio features. Many other reasons, including the well known "cumulative advantage" or [[preferential attachment]] effects deeply contradicts<ref>Pachet, F. (2011) Hit Song Science. [http://www.csl.sony.fr/downloads/papers/2011/pachet-11a.pdf] In Tao, Tzanetakis & Ogihara, editor, Music Data Mining, CRC Press/Chapman Hall</ref> the possibility of practical applications. Nevertheless, automatic prediction techniques are the basis of hit counseling businesses (HSS Technology). Recent work by Herremans et al. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Herremans, D., Martens, D., & Sörensen, K.|title=Dance hit song prediction|journal=Journal of New Music Research|date=2014|volume=43|issue=3|pages=291-302|doi=10.1080/09298215.2014.881888|url=http://dorienherremans.com/sites/default/files/wp_hit.pdf}}</ref> has shown that audio features can indeed be used to outperform a random oracle when predicting top 10 versus top 30-40 hits <ref>[https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/bmvxvm/a-machine-successfully-predicted-the-hit-dance-songs-of-2015 Vice Magazine: A Machine Successfully Predicted the Hit Dance Songs of 2015] </ref>.
==Commercial applications== A technology proposing to exploit Hit Song Science was introduced in 2003 by an artificial intelligence company out of Barcelona, Spain, called [[Polyphonic HMI]]. Polyphonic HMI has since spun off a new Delaware C corporation, Music Intelligence Solutions, Inc., which used to run uPlaya, a site geared toward music professionals. In 2006 however one of the company's founders, [[Mike McCready (music entrepreneur)|Mike McCready]] left to pursue another direction in the digital music space. The idea of Hit Song Science has generated response from many in the music industry, including [[Chuck D]],<ref>[http://www.xxlmag.com/online/?p=51928 XXLmag.com: Chuck D and uPlaya Analyze Hit Songs]</ref> [[Robert Lamm]], [[Stratton Leopold]],<ref>[http://www.redorbit.com/modules/news/tools.php?tool=print&id=1189500 Stratton Leopold to Advisory Board]</ref> Gregg Scholl of [[The Orchard (music label)|The Orchard]],<ref>[http://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2009/06/uplaya-cuts-multitiered-alliance-with-the-orchard.html Music Intelligence Solutions Partners with The Orchard]</ref> and officials at The Sync Agency<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS55195+16-Jun-2008+MW20080616 Music Intelligence Solutions Partners with The Sync Agency]</ref> as well as Blue Infinity Music. Prior to McCready's departure, Hit Song Science was profiled by [[NBC]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6jg70weJWs NBC Network News Feature on uPlaya]</ref> [[BBC]]<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VFuA0MqP8kA BBC News Report]</ref> and various major news outlets. The plot line of an episode of "[[Numb3rs]]"<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJL88mBif6U Episode of "Numb3rs" Inspired by Hit Song Science]</ref> was inspired by the technology. Music Intelligence Solutions, Inc., is using Hit Song Science as a basis for several contests done in partnership with organizations such as [[AllHipHop.com]], [[Urban Latino]] and ''American Songwriter'' magazine, and claims to have predicted the commercial success of [[Norah Jones]]'s debut album, ''[[Come Away with Me]]'', (which won a Grammy for Best Album) and Ben Novak's debut single, "[[Turn Your Car Around]]", which reached the number 12 spot in the UK Top 40 charts.<ref>[http://uplaya.com/about_hss/hssquotes Ben Novak's debut single enters the UK Top 40 chart at number 12]</ref>
Similar technologies are now emerging with companies such as [[Mixcloud]], [http://www.musicxray.com MusicXray], and [http://bandmetrics.com/ BandMetrics] who are using their technologies. Mixcloud is working with Queen Mary Technologies.

'''Kuba Divination''' is a form of [[divination]] used by the [[Kuba Kingdom|Kuba]] people of central Africa.
Kuba divination is practiced by specialists called ''ngwoom''. According to historian John Mack, divination is used to gain access to the knowledge which only the spirits, called ''[[ngesh]]'', possess about the source of social and physical ills which may affect a community. It serves two main purposes: detection of thieves, and determining the cause of illness.<ref name=":0">Mack, John. "Animal Representations in Kuba Art: An Anthropological Interpretation of Sculpture" in ''Oxford Art Journal'', Vol. 4, No. 2, Sculpture (Nov., 1981), pp. 50-56Published by: Oxford University PressArticle Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1360140</ref>
==Ngwoom== [[Kuba Kingdom|Kuba]] diviners (''ngwoom'') maintain the proper relationship between ''[[ngesh]]'' and humans. Even with the establishment of [[Christian church]] congregations in many Kuba communities during the 20th Century, ''ngwoom'' and other specialists whose expertise derives from ''ngesh'' continue to practice.<ref name="Binkley 2009" />
==Itoom== [[File:Brooklyn Museum 22.812 Diviners Instrument Itoom (3).jpg|thumbnail|Kuba itoom, divining discs missing, from the collection of the Brooklyn Museum]] Rubbing oracles (''itoom'') were used by Kuba ''ngwoom'' during the nineteenth and the first half of the twentieth centuries. This practice was adopted from the related [[Kete language|Kete]] and employed extensively by the Kuba.
''Itoom'' all functioned in the same manner: a small wooden disc with a smooth base and a projecting knob was rubbed across the surface of the ''itoom'' by the ''ngwoom'' while he or she uttered a series of names or formulas. When the moving disk abruptly stopped, the desired information was disclosed.
Most ''itoom'' were created in the form of a naturalistic or abstract representation of an animal. The most common animals represented, such as the crocodile, warthog, lizard, and dog, were associated with the forest and surrounding natural habitat.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Binkley 2009">{{cite book|last=Binkley|first=David A|title=Kuba|year=2009|publisher=5 Continents Edition|location=Milan|author2=Patricia Darish }}</ref>
