====Tobacco industry response==== In August 2010, [[Philip Morris International]], [[British American Tobacco]] and [[Imperial Tobacco]] formed the Alliance of Australian Retailers, which commenced a multimillion-dollar campaign against the introduction of plain cigarette packaging. The campaign focused on [[grassroots]] advocacy ([[astroturfing]]), ostensibly on behalf of small business owners.<ref>{{cite news |title=Big tobacco bankrolls anti-Labor ad campaign |first=Jennifer |last=Macey |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/04/2972779.htm |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=4 August 2010}}</ref> When the funding source of the campaign was made public, large retailers such as [[Coles Supermarkets|Coles]] and [[Woolworths (supermarket)|Woolworths]] quickly withdrew support for the campaign.<ref>{{cite news |title=Retail group quits cigarette label campaign |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/08/11/2979583.htm |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=11 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Leaks reveal $9m tobacco blitz |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/09/11/3009026.htm |work=[[Lateline]]|date=10 September 2010}}</ref> The tobacco companies subsequently hired a [[public relations]] firm to oversee the campaign.<ref>{{cite news|title=Big Tobacco hired public relations firm to lobby government|first=Anne|last=Davies|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/big-tobacco-hired-public-relations-firm-to-lobby-government-20100910-154yg.html|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=11 September 2010}}</ref>
In May 2011, [[British American Tobacco]] launched a media campaign suggesting that illicit trade and crime syndicates would benefit from plain packaging.<ref>[http://www.plainpack.com/home.aspx Plain Packs Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520232024/http://www.plainpack.com/home.aspx |date=20 May 2011 }}</ref> BATA [[CEO]] David Crow threatened to lower cigarette prices in order to compete, which he claimed could result in higher levels of smoking amongst young people.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tobacco Companies Declare War |url=http://www.abc.net.au/insiders/content/2011/s3223432.htm |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]}}</ref> Mr. Crow later commented he would tell his own children not to smoke cigarettes, because they are unhealthy.<ref>{{cite news |title=British American Tobacco Australia boss David Crow tells his kids not to smoke |first=Stephen |last=Johnson |url=http://www.news.com.au/business/british-american-tobacco-australia-boss-david-crow-tells-his-children-not-to-smoke/story-e6frfm1i-1226059590411|publisher=news.com.au |date=20 May 2011}}</ref>
The BATA campaign is largely based on a report from [[Deloitte]]. Several of the claims contained in the report related to border protection, and have since been publicly refuted by customs officials, and the report itself indicated that it had relied extensively on unaudited figures supplied by the tobacco industry itself.<ref>[http://www.ashaust.org.au/lv4/IllicitChapman1103.htm Professor Simon Chapman] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120719094702/http://www.ashaust.org.au/lv4/IllicitChapman1103.htm |date=19 July 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=It's plain to see what's behind the smokescreen |first=Jessica |last=Irvine |url=http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/politics/its-plain-to-see-whats-behind-the-smokescreen-20110519-1eusy.html|work=[[The Age]]|date=20 May 2011 |location=Melbourne}}</ref>
In June 2011, [[Imperial Tobacco]] Australia launched a secondary media campaign, deriding plain packaging legislation as part of a [[Nanny state]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Big Tobacco takes on the nanny state |url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/business/9636433/big-tobacco-takes-on-nanny-state/ |publisher=Yahoo Australia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623083821/http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/business/9636433/big-tobacco-takes-on-nanny-state |archivedate=23 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In June 2011, Philip Morris International announced it was using the provisions in a Hong Kong/Australia treaty to demand compensation for Australia's plain packaging anti-smoking legislation. As a US-based company, Philip Morris could not sue under the US-Australia Free Trade Agreement. The company rearranged its assets to become a Hong Kong investor in order to use the [[investor-state dispute settlement]] provisions in the Australia-Hong Kong Bilateral Investment treaty (BIT).<ref name="AFTINET"/> Immediately following the passage of legislation on 21 November 2011, Philip Morris announced it had served a notice of arbitration under Australia's Bilateral Investment Treaty with Hong Kong, seeking the suspension on the plain packaging laws and compensation for the loss of trademarks.<ref name="ABC News" /> [[Allens (law firm)|Allens Arthur Robinson]] represented Philip Morris.<ref>{{cite news |title=Philip Morris Begins Arbitration Proceedings With Australia Over Tobacco Packaging Law |url=http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202533316269&slreturn=1|author=Ben Lewis |publisher=LAW.COM|date=23 November 2011}} {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref> In response, Health Minister [[Nicola Roxon]] stated that she believed the government was "on very strong ground" legally, and that the government was willing to defend the measures.<ref name=ABC6Jul2011 /><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mccabecentre.org/focus-areas/tobacco/philip-morris-asia-challenge|title = Philip Morris Asia Challenge under Australia – Hong Kong Bilateral Investment Treaty|accessdate = 2014-12-05|publisher = McCabe Centre for Law and Cancer}}</ref> The continuance of trade and investment proceedings on the issue has been described as an affront to the rule of law in Australia.<ref>Faunce TA. Affront to the Rule of Law-international tribunal to decide on plain packaging The Conversation 29 August 2012 https://theconversation.edu.au/an-affront-to-the-rule-of-law-international-tribunals-to-decide-on-plain-packaging-8968 (accessed 29 August 2012)</ref> Dr Patricia Ranald, Convener of the Australian Fair Trade and Investment Network said that big tobacco and other global corporations are lobbying hard to include the right of foreign investors to sue governments in the current negotiations for a Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPPA).<ref name="AFTINET"/> Philip Morris International lost its case in December 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title=Australia wins international legal battle with Philip Morris over plain packaging |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/dec/18/australia-wins-international-legal-battle-with-philip-morris-over-plain-packaging |publisher=[[the Guardian]]|date= 2015-12-18}}</ref>
In November 2011, British American Tobacco announced that it would challenge the laws in the High Court as soon as they gained royal assent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plain cigarette packaging to start in 2012|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/plain-cigarette-packaging-to-start-in-2012-20111121-1nqbo.html|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=21 November 2011}}</ref> In August 2012, the High Court ruled in favour of the Australian government.<ref>{{cite AustLII |litigants=JT International SA v Commonwealth |court=HCA |num=43 |year=2012 |parallelcite=(2011) 250 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 1 [http://www.hcourt.gov.au/assets/publications/judgment-summaries/2012/projt-2012-08-15.pdf judgement summary] at High Court of Australia Website.}}</ref>
British American Tobacco placed [[freedom of information]] requests on a Cancer Institute NSW research survey of school students aged between 12-17, which asked how they react to plain packaging, where they get cigarettes from and what age they started smoking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/tobacco-company-wants-schools-survey-for-insights-into-children-and-teens-20150819-gj2vto.html|title=Tobacco company wants schools survey for insights into children and teens|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-20/cancer-council-fights-tobacco-giant-foi-bid-for-info-on-smoking/6710884|title=Cancer Council to fight British American Tobacco's FOI bid for students' smoking attitudes research|work=ABC News|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> The [[Cancer Council Victoria]] fought the FOI request, saying that the tobacco company wanted to use the survey information to change their marketing to children to increase cigarette smoking among youth.
Phillip Morris was ordered to pay the Australian government's legal fees.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Knaus |first1=Christopher |title=Philip Morris cigarettes charged millions after losing plain packaging case against Australia |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/jul/10/philip-morris-cigarettes-charged-millions-after-losing-plain-packaging-case-against-australia |accessdate=1 July 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=10 July 2017 |language=en}}</ref> A FOI request by [[Nick Xenophon]] and [[Rex Patrick]] revealed that Australia's legal fees amounted to $39 million with Patrick saying that this showed the dangers of investor-state dispute settlement clauses allowing companies to sue governments in the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hutchens |first1=Gareth |last2=Knaus |first2=Christopher |title=Revealed: $39m cost of defending Australia's tobacco plain packaging laws |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jul/02/revealed-39m-cost-of-defending-australias-tobacco-plain-packaging-laws |accessdate=1 July 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=1 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
====Other responses==== The [[World Health Organization]] applauded Australia’s law on plain packaging noting that “the legislation sets a new global standard for the control of a product that accounts for nearly 6 million deaths each year".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/press_releases/pr_20111123.htm |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20111124102118/http%3A//www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/press_releases/pr_20111123.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 November 2011 |title=WHO applauds Australia's new tobacco packaging legislation |author= |date=23 November 2011 |publisher=World Health Organization |accessdate=15 February 2012 }}</ref>
The Cancer Council of Australia hailed the passing of the legislation, stating, "Documents obtained from the tobacco industry show how much the tobacco companies rely on pack design to attract new smokers....You only have to look at how desperate the tobacco companies are to stop plain packaging, for confirmation that pack design is seen as critical to sales."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cancer.org.au//Newsmedia/mediareleases/mediareleases2011/21November2011.htm |title=Great day in public health, as parliament signs off on tobacco packaging bills |author=Paul Grogan |date=21 November 2011|publisher=Cancer Council, Australia |accessdate=23 November 2011}}</ref> The World Health Organization's director for the Western Pacific also congratulated Australia and stated that all countries and areas in the Western Pacific should follow Australia's good example.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://solomontimes.com/news.aspx?nwID=6670 |title=WHO Applauds Australia's New Tobacco Packaging Legislation |author=World Health Organization |date=23 November 2011|work=Solomon Times Online |accessdate=24 November 2011}}</ref>
Speaking on Radio Australia, Don Rothwell, Professor of International Law at the [[Australian National University]], noted that Philip Morris was pursuing multiple legal avenues. The Notice of Arbitration under the bilateral investment treaty between Hong Kong and Australia has a 90-day cooling off period after which the case would most likely be sent to the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes in Washington. He stated that Philip Morris was most likely aiming for the Australian Government to back down, or failing that, to sue for compensation. He said the questions to decide are whether the legislation means that Australia would acquire property by the imposition of these rules and if this legislation is a legitimate public-health measure.
Professor Rothwell noted "...the growing recognition of the legitimacy of public health measures of this type." Professor Rothwell estimated that the legal cases, including any case before the High Court, would take up to a year to decide.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/asiapac/stories/201111/s3373582.htm|title=Australia sued over cigarette plain packaging laws |date=22 November 2011|publisher=ABC International Radio Australia|accessdate= 26 November 2011}}</ref> However, in the United States, Judge Richard J. Leon ruled in 2011 that graphic health warning labels "clearly display the government’s opinion on smoking" which he said "cannot constitutionally be required to appear on the merchandise of private companies." He ruled that these warnings would unfairly hurt their sales, that the warnings were crafted to provoke an emotional response calculated to quit smoking or never to start smoking. This, the judge ruled, was "an objective wholly apart from disseminating purely factual and uncontroversial information." This finding may be appealed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bpr.berkeley.edu/2011/11/federal-judge-deems-fda’s-antismoking-warning-labels-unconstitutional/ |title=Federal Judge Deems FDA's Antismoking Warning Labels Unconstitutional |author=Mandy Honeychurch |date=8 November 2011 |work=Berkeley Political Review |accessdate=26 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710004624/http://bpr.berkeley.edu/2011/11/federal-judge-deems-fda%E2%80%99s-antismoking-warning-labels-unconstitutional/ |archivedate=10 July 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-57320454-10391704/fdas-graphic-cigarette-warning-labels-beyond-free-speech/ |title=FDA's graphic cigarette warning labels: Beyond free speech? |author=Ryan Jaslow |date=8 November 2011|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc |accessdate=26 November 2011}}</ref>{{Update inline|date=June 2017}}
The Associated Press noted that Philip Morris took "less than an hour" to launch legal action against the Australian legislation. It also stated that Australian legislation followed the lead of Uruguay which requires that 80 per cent of cigarette packages is devoted to warnings and Brazil, where cigarette packages display "graphic images" of dead fetuses, haemorrhaging brains and gangrenous feet.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/industries/tobacco-giant-philip-morris-suing-australian-government-over-plain-packaging-law/2011/11/21/gIQA0sE4gN_story.html |title=Australia passes no-logo cigarette package law; Philip Morris quickly takes legal action |author=Associated Press |date=21 November 2011|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=23 November 2011}} {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref>
Gavin Allen of the ''Daily Mail'' newspaper reported that the Philip Morris lawsuit could cost the Australian government "billions". He also noted that the Australian law is being closely watched by other governments in Europe, Canada and New Zealand. In 2005, the World Health Organization urged countries to consider plain packaging, and noted that [[Bhutan]] had banned the sale of tobacco earlier in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2064314/Philip-Morris-challenges-Australian-law-plain-tobacco-packaging.html|title=Cigarette giant Philip Morris sues Australian government for billions over plain packaging law |author=Gavin Allen |date=22 November 2011|work=The Daily Mail|accessdate=23 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
New Zealand Associate Health Minister [[Tariana Turia]] congratulated the Australian Health Minister, noted that tobacco labelling rules have long been harmonised between Australia and New Zealand, and looked forward to New Zealand following suit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-11/22/c_131262227.htm|title=New Zealand to follow Australia's controversial plain packaging law for cigarettes |date= 22 November 2011|publisher=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate= 26 November 2011}}</ref>
====Legislation==== In April 2011, [[Nicola Roxon|Minister Roxon]] released an exposure draft of plain packaging legislation with an expected start date of 1 July 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Exposure Draft, Plain Packaging Bill|first=Nicola|last=Roxon|authorlink=Nicola Roxon|url=http://yourhealth.gov.au/internet/yourhealth/publishing.nsf/Content/C550AA264BA53F7ACA25786B0001B34A/$File/Tobacco%20Plain%20Packaging%20Bill%202011%20-%20Exposure%20Draft%20-%2031%20March%202011.pdf|publisher=Australian Government|date=April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603020321/http://www.yourhealth.gov.au/internet/yourhealth/publishing.nsf/Content/C550AA264BA53F7ACA25786B0001B34A/$File/Tobacco%20Plain%20Packaging%20Bill%202011%20-%20Exposure%20Draft%20-%2031%20March%202011.pdf|archivedate=3 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Australian newspapers reported that the legislation was likely to pass despite concerns from the [[Coalition (Australia)|Opposition]]. It was suggested the Opposition resistance to the legislation was due to their continuing acceptance of funding donations from tobacco companies.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cigarettes Likely to get plain packages |first=Andrea |last=Hayward |url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/cigarettes-likely-to-get-plain-packages-20110524-1f193.html |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=24 May 2011}}</ref>
On 31 May 2011, [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] leader [[Tony Abbott]] announced that his party would support the legislation, and would work with the government to ensure the legislation is effective.<ref>{{cite news |title=Abbott out of puff on plain packet laws |first=Ben |last=Packham |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/abbott-out-of-puff-on-plain-cigarette-packet-laws/story-fn59niix-1226066784420|work=[[The Australian]]|date=1 June 2011}}</ref>
[[Nicola Roxon|Minister Roxon]] introduced the plain packaging bill to Parliament on 6 July 2011,<ref name=ABC6Jul2011>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/07/06/3262578.htm "Roxon Introduces Plain Packaging Bill"], ABC News, 6 July 2011</ref> and it passed through the [[Australian House of Representatives|Lower House]] on 24 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=Plain packaging legislation passes Lower House |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-08-24/plain-packaging-legislation-passes-parliament/2854434 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=25 Aug 2011}}</ref> The legislation passed the [[Australian Senate|Upper House]] on 10 November 2011 with the amended start date of 1 December 2012.<ref name=TobaccoPlainPackagingBill2011 /> Due to the changed start date the legislation returned to the Lower House before being given [[royal assent]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cigarette packaging legislation passes Senate |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-10/plain-packaging-legislation-passes-senate/3658840 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=10 November 2011}}</ref> Legislation finally passed on 21 November 2011.<ref name="ABC News" />
=== Belgium === In March 2015, an early day motion forwarded by deputy [[Catherine Fonck]] to consider plain packaging in Belgium. However, it was opposed and stuck down by the federal Public Health select committee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Les partis de la majorité rejettent le paquet de cigarettes neutre|trans-title=The majority parties reject neutral packaging of cigarettes|language=French|url = http://www.levif.be/actualite/belgique/les-partis-de-la-majorite-rejettent-le-paquet-de-cigarettes-neutre/article-normal-373219.html|website=[[Le Vif]]|date=24 March 2015}}</ref> Later in November 2016, the health minister [[Maggie De Block]] said she is open to idea of plain packaging, once the introduction of plain packaging in France and the UK has been reviewed. This was done on top of a list of new tobacco laws such as increasing taxes and raising the purchasing age to 18.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Delepeleire|first1=Yves|title='Anti-rookplan De Block wordt mager beestje'|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20161106_02559048|work=[[De Standaard]]|language=Dutch|accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
===Canada=== In 2011, Health Canada introduced changes to the tobacco products labelling regulations that included sixteen new graphic health warnings covering 75% of the principal faces of cigarette and cigarillo packages. As of September 2015, Health Canada is not planning regulatory action that would require plain or standardised packaging of tobacco products. The department considers its commitment to introduce health-related labelling requirements on cigarettes and cigarillos fulfilled.<ref>Health Canada Controlled Substances and Tobacco Directorate (personal communication, 9 September 2015) {{original research inline|date=June 2017}}</ref>
In early-October 2015, the Liberal Political Party leader, [[Justin Trudeau]], announced that he would include the introduction of plain tobacco packaging as part of his platform, under the heading of Healthier Kids.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liberal.ca/realchange/healthier-kids/|title= Healthier kids|publisher=|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> He has received positive feedback from cancer advocacy groups, including the Canadian Cancer Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cancer.ca/en/about-us/for-media/media-releases/national/2015/plain-packaging-proposal/?region=on|title=Society welcomes commitment to tobacco plain packaging|work=www.cancer.ca|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> He has since become the Prime Minister and has told his then-Health Minister, [[Jane Philpott]], that he expects her to "Introduce plain packaging requirements for tobacco products, similar to those in Australia and the United Kingdom".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/minister-health-mandate-letter|title= Minister of Health Mandate Letter|accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref>
===Colombia=== In March 2015, a bill similar to the Australian one was established before the Congress of the Republic, since it was intended to regulate the packaging and labeling of tobacco products. The ultimate goal of this Bill was to achieve a total ban on its advertising, promotion and sponsorship. Although the Bill was filed a few months after the passage of the legislature, the one that has come to be debated in the first presentation in the House of Representatives allows concluding that Colombia is not far from adopting a regulation on the matter.<ref>{{cite news |title=The arrival of Plain Packaging to Colombia |url=https://www.asuntoslegales.com.co/consultorio/la-llegada-del-plain-packaging-a-colombia-2611247 |publisher=[[Asuntos Legales]]|date=16 March 2016|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
===European Union=== In 2010, the European Commission launched a public consultation<ref>{{cite news |title=Public consultation on the possible revision of the Tobacco Products Directive 2001/37/EC |url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/tobacco/consultations/tobacco_cons_01_en.htm |publisher=[[European Commission]]|date=24 September 2010| accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> on a proposal to revise Directive 2001/37/EC which covers health warnings, limits on toxic constituents, etc., for tobacco products. The consultation included a proposal to require plain packaging. Although [[John Dalli|Commissioner Dalli]] has rejected plain packaging as an option,<ref>{{cite news |title=Plain packaging proposals for tobacco will 'damage business'|publisher=Talking retail|url=http://www.talkingretail.com/news/industry-news/plain-packaging-proposals-for-tobacco-will-%E2%80%98damage-business%E2%80%99|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> the European Union included in its proposal for a new [[Tobacco Products Directive]], which became applicable in EU countries in May 2016,<ref name=EU2014>{{cite web|title=European Union: Tobacco Products Directive (2014/40/EU)|url=https://ec.europa.eu/health/tobacco/products_en|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> the option for the Member States to introduce plain packaging.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://ec.europa.eu/health/tobacco/docs/com_2012_788_en.pdf|title= Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States concerning the manufacture, presentation and sale of tobacco and related products|date= 19 December 2012 |accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref> Legal scholars consider plain packaging to be consistent with primary European law<ref>{{cite journal|last=Henning|first=Peter K.|author2=Shmatenko, Leonid|title=Plain Packaging on Its Way to Europe: Competence Issues and Compatibility with European Fundamental Rights|journal=Transnational Dispute Management|date=November 2012|volume=9|issue=5|pages=1–17|ssrn=2171205|accessdate=}}</ref> and German law.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shmatenko|first=Leonid|title=Verfassungsmäßigkeit von Einheitsverpackungen (Plain Packaging) bei Zigaretten|journal=Juristische Ausbildung (JURA)|date=February 2013|volume=35|issue=2|pages=74–81|url=http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/jura-2013-35-issue-2/jura-2013-0016/jura-2013-0016.xml?format=INT|accessdate=5 March 2013|doi=10.1515/jura-2012-0016}}</ref>
The directive adopted April 3, 2014 explicitly states that 28 EU countries have the option of implementing plain packaging, a provision upheld on May 4, 2016 by the [[European Court of Justice]] as valid when dismissing a tobacco industry legal challenge.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf;jsessionid=9ea7d2dc30ddfe90e0aea11f458dbae3c7bf29452f35.e34KaxiLc3qMb40Rch0SaxuSahr0?text=&docid=173256&pageIndex=0&doclang=en&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=493911|title=Case C‑547/14: Philip Morris Brands SARL and Others}}</ref>
===France=== In December 2010, a [[Union for a Popular Movement|UMP]] member of the French Parliament tabled a Member's Bill aimed at creating plain cigarette packaging. However, the bill did not pass despite ongoing support from health associations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tabac: la Ligue contre le cancer veut des paquets de cigarettes "neutres" |trans-title=Tobacco: the league against cancer wants "neutral" packets of cigarettes |language=French |url=http://lci.tf1.fr/filnews/science/tabac-la-ligue-contre-le-cancer-veut-des-paquets-de-cigarettes-6968916.html |publisher=LCI, TF1 |date=1 February 2012 |accessdate=15 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212130556/http://lci.tf1.fr/filnews/science/tabac-la-ligue-contre-le-cancer-veut-des-paquets-de-cigarettes-6968916.html |archivedate=12 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> As in other countries, there was fierce protest from the tobacco industry and tobacco retailers associations. The Health Minister also seemed lukewarm in his support, preferring to see the effect of newly-introduced health warnings.<ref>{{cite news |title=Plain cigarette packets considered |url=http://www.connexionfrance.com/plain-cigarette-packets-smoking-draft-law-logos-colours-banned-shock-images-view-article.html |publisher=The Connection|date=11 August 2010|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
Under the next legislature however, the new [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist]] Health Minister, [[Marisol Touraine]], said she would fight especially at the European level for "neutral packaging". As in Australia, the tobacco industry countered that generic packaging would be easy to counterfeit, which would increase illegal cigarette sales.<ref>{{cite news|title=Le gouvernement favorable à des "cigarettes neutres" |trans-title= The government is favourable towards "neutral cigarettes" |language=French |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/sante/article/2012/07/31/le-gouvernement-favorable-a-des-paquets-de-cigarettes-neutres_1740749_1651302.html |work=[[Le Monde]]|date=31 July 2012}}</ref> The EU directive eventually contained no explicit measures regarding plain packaging. In reaction, the French government announced the introduction of a bill containing provisions for generic cigarette packaging on 25 September 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Encadrement du vapotage, mise en place du paquet " neutre " : les annonces du plan anti-tabac |trans-title=Supervision of vaping, implementation of the "neutral" packet: announcements of the plan against tobacco |language=French|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/sante/article/2014/09/25/encadrement-du-vapotage-mise-en-place-du-paquet-neutre-les-annonces-du-plan-anti-tabac_4494262_1651302.html|work=Le Monde|date=25 September 2014}}</ref> The bill was passed on 17 December 2015. The tobacco industry promptly attacked it in court, but lost its case. This legislation was upheld on 21 January 2016 as constitutional by France’s [[Constitutional Council (France)|Constitutional Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/francais/les-decisions/acces-par-date/decisions-depuis-1959/2016/2015-727-dc/decision-n-2015-727-dc-du-21-janvier-2016.146887.html|title=Décision n° 2015-727 DC du 21 janvier 2016 sur la loi de modernisation du système de santé}}</ref>
Cigarettes manufactured after 20 May 2016 or sold after 1 January 2017 must be put in plain packaging.<ref>{{cite news|title=La France adopte le paquet de cigarettes neutre|trans-title=France adopts neutral cigarette packaging|language=French|url=http://www.lesoir.be/1072520/article/actualite/fil-info/fil-info-monde/2015-12-17/france-adopte-paquet-cigarettes-neutre|date=17 December 2015}} {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref>
===Hungary=== The Decree of 16 August 2016 requires that new cigarette and tobacco brands that will be introduced on the Hungarian market after 20 August 2016 has to be in a uniform plain packaging, void of brand logos. Eventually, all cigarette and tobacco products are to be sold in uniform packs from 20 May 2019.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hungary: Larger pictorial warnings and plain packaging required by the new Government Decree|url=http://apps.who.int/fctc/implementation/database/groups/hungary-larger-pictorial-warnings-and-plain-packaging-required-new-government-decree}}</ref>
As of July 2017, the first cigarettes with unified plain packaging hit the Hungarian market. From 20 August 2016 onwards, new brands have to be sold in plain packaging, one new cigarette brand of Von Eicken GmbH was forced to be launched with such unified package. This makes Hungary the fourth country in the world, where plain packaging is enforced; after Australia, France and the UK.
===India=== As of August 2012, India is believed to be considering plain packaging.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/business/tobacco-fight-not-over-phillip-morris-says-20120815-2488s.html "Tobacco fight not over, Phillip Morris says"], by Chris Zappone, ''[[The Age]]'', 15 August 2012. Accessed 15 August 2012</ref> [[Biju Janata Dal|BJD]] MP of Orissa, [[Baijayant Panda|Baijayant Jay Panda]], has submitted in the [[Lok Sabha]] a private members bill seeking an amendment to the anti-tobacco law aimed at increasing the size of health warning on tobacco product packets. The bill seeks amendment to the original act from 2003 to stipulate for plain packaging of cigarette and tobacco products in the country and increase the size of health warning and the accompanying graphic on cigarette packets.<ref>[http://www.business-standard.com/generalnews/news/bill-submitted-in-lok-sabha-for-amending-tobacco-act-2003/56442/ "Bill submitted in Lok Sabha for amending tobacco act 2003"], ''[[Business Standard]]'', 14 September 2012. Accessed 10 October 2012</ref> As of 2017, there has been no progress on this matter and tobacco continues to be sold in branded packaging.
===Ireland=== In May 2013, Ireland announced plans to become the second country in the world to introduce plain cigarette packaging.<ref>[http://www.dohc.ie/press/releases/2013/20130528.html "Ireland set to become second country in the world to introduce plain pack cigarettes"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222055922/http://www.dohc.ie/press/releases/2013/20130528.html |date=22 February 2014 }}, by Ireland's DoHC, 28 May 2013. Accessed 28 May 2013</ref> In June 2014, the Irish government said it would legislate to implement plain packaging. Details of the bill known as the ''Public Health (Standardised Packaging of Tobacco) Bill 2014'' were published on 10 June 2014. "There is a wealth of international evidence on the effects of tobacco packaging in general and on perceptions and reactions to standardised packaging which support the introduction of this measure," Ireland's [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Health Minister]] [[James Reilly (Irish politician)|James Reilly]] said when releasing details of the bill.<ref name="IrishPackagingBan">{{cite news|title=Ireland to become first country in Europe to restrict tobacco companies on packaging|url=http://www.irishsun.com/index.php/sid/222782481/scat/aba4168066a10b8d/ht/Ireland-to-become-first-country-in-Europe-to-restrict-tobacco-companies-on-packaging|accessdate=10 June 2014|publisher=''Irish Sun.com''}}</ref> The bill was signed by [[President of Ireland|President]] [[Michael D. Higgins]] on 10 March 2015. After some delays, it was announced that the law would take effect on 30 September 2017, with the sale of previously-manufactured cigarettes allowed until 30 September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plain packaging for cigarettes to begin in September|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/plain-packaging-for-cigarettes-to-begin-in-september-1.3028834|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Malaysia === On 24 February 2016, the [[Malaysia]]n [[Ministry of Health (Malaysia)|health ministry]] announced that it is planning to follow Australia's example and introduce plain packaging for tobacco in the near future.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gov’t plans to introduce plain packaging for tobacco|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2016/02/24/govt-plans-to-introduce-plain-packaging-for-tobacco/|accessdate=1 April 2016|work=Free Malaysia News|date=24 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Malaysia faces fight over plain tobacco packaging|url=http://english.cntv.cn/2016/03/15/VIDEmUynjaejCUujnTHCO37q160315.shtml|work=CCTV.com English|date=15 March 2016}}</ref>
=== The Netherlands === In the Netherlands, [[Paul Blokhuis]], serving as [[Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport (Netherlands)|State Secretary for Health, Welfare and Sports]] in the [[Third Rutte cabinet]] plans to have plain packaging law by 2020<ref>[https://www.telegraaf.nl/nieuws/2499077/plan-staatssecretaris-blokhuis-sigarettenpakjes-krijgen-neutrale-kleur De Telegraaf: Sigarettenpakjes krijgen neutrale kleur]</ref>.
===New Zealand=== New Zealand requires tobacco products to be standardised in a similar manner to Australian requirements. Legislation and associated regulations to enable standardised packaging of tobacco products came into force on 14 March 2018.<ref name= "NZ Parliament">New Zealand Parliament. [http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2016/0043/latest/DLM5821012.html?search=ts_act%40bill%40regulation%40deemedreg_Smoke-free_resel_25_a&p=1 "Smoke-free Environments (Tobacco Standardised Packaging) Amendment Act 2016"], ''Government Legislation'', September 2016. Retrieved on 16 September 2016.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/2017/0123/latest/whole.html|title= Smoke-free Environments Regulations 2017. Order in Council|date= 6 June 2017|access-date= 13 June 2017}}.</ref> Distributors were given six weeks to clear old stock and following this retailers were given a further six weeks to dispose of old stock.<ref name= "NZ Parliament" /> As a result, only standardised tobacco packaging was permissible after 6 June 2018.
Discussion of the need for standardised packaging (formerly called plain packaging), the passage of the legislation through Parliament, and its subsequent coming into force took six years. In April 2012, following an inquiry by the Māori Affairs Select Committee, Government (on recommendation of the then Associate Minister of Health, Dame [[Tariana Turia]]) approved plain packaging in principle, a move that tobacco companies said they would strenuously oppose.<ref>Otago Daily Times. [http://www.odt.co.nz/news/national/206216/cigarette-pack-rules-have-makers-fuming html "Cigarette pack rules have makers fuming"], ''[[Otago Daily Times]]'', 20 April 2012. Retrieved on 4 May 2015.</ref> From July to October 2012 the Ministry of Health undertook a consultation which attracted over 20,000 submissions (including overseas submissions) from public health groups and also the tobacco industry.<ref>Ministry of Health. [http://www.health.govt.nz/publication/proposal-introduce-plain-packaging-tobacco-products-new-zealand html "Proposal to introduce plain packaging of tobacco products in New Zealand"], '[[New Zealand Ministry of Health]]'', 23 July 2012. Retrieved on 4 May 2015.</ref> In February 2013 Government decided to proceed with legislative change in alignment with Australia. A Bill to require the plain packaging of tobacco products – the Smoke-free Environments (Tobacco Plain Packaging) Amendment Bill<ref>Parliamentary Counsel Office. [http://www.legislation.govt.nz/bill/government/2013/0186/latest/DLM5821008.html?src=qs html "Smoke-free Environments (Tobacco Plain Packaging) Amendment Bill"], House of Representatives, Retrieved on 4 May 2015.</ref> – was introduced on 17 December 2013.<ref name="parliament.nz">New Zealand Parliament. [http://www.parliament.nz/en-nz/pb/legislation/bills/00DBHOH_BILL12969_1/smoke-free-environments-tobacco-plain-packaging-amendment html " Smoke-free Environments (Tobacco Plain Packaging) Amendment Bill "], House of Representatives, Retrieved on 4 May 2015.</ref> The Bill had its first reading on 11 February 2014.<ref name="parliament.nz"/> It was referred to the Health Committee for consideration which reported it back to Parliament with minor amendments on 11 August 2014<ref name="parliament.nz"/> including a change in title from ‘Plain Packaging’ to ‘Standardised Packaging’. The Bill was stalled due to concern over legal action against the Australian government’s plain packaging regime.<ref>New Zealand News. [http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/235694/minister-defends-plain-packaging html "Minister defends plain packaging"], ''[[Radio New Zealand News]]'', 10 February 2014. Retrieved on 2 May 2015.</ref> However, in February 2016, [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Prime Minister]] [[John Key]] commented that there was now firm legal ground for plain packaging and that the measure could become law by the end of 2016.<ref>Stuff.co.nz. [http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/76917027/tobacco-plain-packaging-likely-to-be-law-by-end-of-year--john-key], ''[[Stuff.co.nz]]'', 15 February 2016. Retrieved on 2 June 2016.</ref> On 30 June 2016, the Bill was given its second reading<ref>Hansard (Debates)[https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/hansard-debates/rhr/combined/HansDeb_20160630_20160630_20],''[[New Zealand Parliament]]'', 30 June 2016. Retrieved 5 July 2016.</ref> with consideration by the Committee of the Whole House on 23 August 2016<ref>New Zealand Parliament. [https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/hansard-debates/rhr/combined/HansD_20160823_20160824], ''Hansard Debates'', 23 August 2016. Retrieved on 14 September 2016.</ref> and the third and final reading on 8 September 2016.<ref>New Zealand Parliament. [https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/hansard-debates/rhr/combined/HansD_20160908_20160908], ''Hansard Debates'', 8 September 2016. Retrieved on 14 September 2016.</ref>
On 31 May 2016, (World No Tobacco Day) the Associate Minister of Health, [[Peseta Sam Lotu-Iiga]], released a consultation document on the detail of standardised packaging requirements.<ref>Scoop Independent News. [http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1605/S00649/standardised-packaging-regulations-released.htm], ''[[Scoop Independent News]]'', 31 May 2016. Retrieved on 2 June 2016.</ref> An [[Order in Council]] was issued on 6 June 2017, making the Smoke-free Environments Regulations 2017 specifying detailed requirements for the standardised design of tobacco packages and products, and also specifying requirements for new and larger warning messages for tobacco packaging. These Regulations came into force on 14 March 2018 and since the 6 June 2018, only standardised packages have been allowed for sale in New Zealand.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.health.govt.nz/our-work/preventative-health-wellness/tobacco-control/plain-packaging|title= Tobacco standardised packaging|website= Ministry of Health (New Zealand)|access-date= 13 June 2017}}.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.legislation.govt.nz/regulation/public/2017/0123/latest/whole.html|title= Smoke-free Environments Regulations 2017. Order in Council|date= 6 June 2017|access-date= 13 June 2017}}.</ref>
===Norway=== In August 2012, it was believed that Norway began considering plain packaging.<ref name="theage.com.au">{{cite news|last = Zappone|first = Chris|title = Tobacco fight not over, Phillip Morris says|url = http://www.theage.com.au/business/tobacco-fight-not-over-phillip-morris-says-20120815-2488s.html#poll|accessdate = 2012-08-15|newspaper = The Age|date = 2012-08-15|location = Melbourne}}</ref> On the 31 May 2016 on [[World No Tobacco Day]], the Health Minister [[Bent Høie]] announced the introduction of plain packaging to Norway by 2017. The plain packaging rule applies to [[snus]] as well as cigarettes.<ref>{{cite news|last =Deshaye|first =Pierre-Henry|title = Norway backs plain packets for cigarettes|url = http://www.thelocal.no/20160531/norway-backs-plain-packets-for-cigarettes|accessdate = 2017-01-02|newspaper = The Local Norway|date = 2016-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Towards a tobacco-free generation|url=https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/towards-a-tobacco-free-generation/id2502147/|website=Government.no|accessdate=31 May 2016}}</ref> In December 2016, the [[Norwegian Parliament]] voted overwhelmingly in favour of implementing standardised packaging for tobacco products.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norway adopts standardised packaging|url=http://www.uicc.org/norway-adopts-standardised-packaging-save-lives-and-prevent-suffering-tobacco-use}}</ref> The measure was introduced at the same time as the EU Tobacco Products Directive measures on packaging and labelling, taking effect on 1 July 2017. Retailers were given one year (until 1 July 2018) to transition to the new standardised cigarette packages and smokeless tobacco boxes.<ref>{{cite news|title=''Norway'' Tobacco labelling Resource Centre|url=http://www.tobaccolabels.ca/countries/norway/}}</ref>
===Panama=== Since 2017, the National Assembly has discussed draft Law 136 on plain packaging.<ref>{{cite news |title=Panama advocates neutral packaging of cigarettes |url=https://www.prensa.com/salud_y_ciencia/Panama-aboga-empaquetado-neutro-cigarrillo_0_4502549836.html |publisher=[[La Prensa (Panama City)|La Prensa]]|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> The bill proposes that the color of the packs be dark matt gray and that the mark be presented in white Arial font, size 20, highlighted in bold. Panama ranks second in having the lowest prevalence in the world of consumption, since only 6.4% of adults in the isthmus smoke.
===Philippines=== Anti-smoking group New Vois Association of the Philippines favored the introduction of plain cigarette packaging in the Philippines as part of their campaign on the 2016 [[World No Tobacco Day]] and urged then-presumptive president [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to implement a law to standardize cigarette packs. The [[Department of Health (Philippines)|Department of Health]] (DOH), however, is not ready to implement plain cigarette packaging, and rather focus on enforcing [[Tobacco packaging warning message|graphic health warnings]] on cigarette packs under the Graphic Health Warning Act of 2014 that took effect in March 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anti-smoking group urges Duterte to adopt plain-packed cigarettes|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2016/05/30/anti-smoking-group-urges-duterte-adopt-plain-packed-cigarettes-476525|newspaper=[[Sun.Star]]|date=30 May 2016|accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref>
===Slovenia=== On the 15 February 2017, the [[Parliament of Slovenia]] passed a law for the introduction of plain packaging from 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=Slovenia passes law enforcing plain tobacco packaging from 2020|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-tobacco-idUSKBN15U2BI|website=Reuters|accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Switzerland === On 5 December 2014, [[National Council (Switzerland)|Swiss parliamentarian]] Pierre-Alain Fridez tabled a motion for plain packaging in Switzerland. A few days later, [[Federal Council of Switzerland|the Federal Council]] said it was opposed to this, saying such a measure "goes too far".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lematin.ch/suisse/Le-Conseil-federal-s-oppose-aux-paquets-de-cigarettes-neutres/story/31905395|title=Le Conseil fédéral s'oppose aux paquets de cigarettes neutres|trans-title=The Federal Council opposes neutral packets of cigarettes|language=French|work= [[Le Matin (Switzerland)|Le Matin]]|date=8 December 2014}}</ref>
===Turkey=== In September 2011, ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' reported that the Turkish government was working on plain packaging regulations. An Istanbul-based newspaper, ''[[Milliyet]]'', reported that under the proposal all branding elements would disappear and cigarettes would come in "numbered black boxes" excluding any imagery other than health warnings.<ref>{{cite news |title=Turkey Working on Cigarette Branding Ban Law, Milliyet Says |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-09-07/turkey-working-on-cigarette-branding-ban-law-milliyet-says.html |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=7 September 2011|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In November 2016, Health Minister [[Recep Akdağ]] stated that Turkey will "introduce plain packaging where the brand of cigarettes will almost be invisible and sellers will be obliged to store the cigarettes in closed cases instead of transparent displays" in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=New restrictions on cigarette sales in the works|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/turkey/2016/11/15/new-restrictions-on-cigarette-sales-in-the-works|website=The Daily Sabah|accessdate=21 April 2017|location=Ankara, Turkey|date=14 November 2016}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In November 2013, the UK Government announced an independent review of cigarette packaging in the UK, amid calls for action to discourage young smokers.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news |title=Cigarette packaging: Ministers launch fresh review |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-25126673|accessdate=28 November 2013 | work=BBC News |date=28 November 2013}}</ref> Public Health Minister Jane Ellison rejected [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] calls for immediate regulation rather than a review, saying: "It's a year this weekend since the legislation was introduced in Australia. It's the right time to ask people to look at this."
The "Plain Packs Protect" campaign by an alliance of health organisations set out the case for tobacco plain packaging in the UK, as did Cancer Research UK's "The Answer Is Plain" campaign, which was launched soon after the government consultation was announced. Opposing this was the smokers' rights group [[FOREST]], which launched a counter-campaign titled "Hands Off Our Packs".<ref name=BBC />
In March 2015, the House of Commons voted 367–113 in favour of introducing plain cigarette packaging. Plain packaging is required for cigarettes manufactured after 20 May 2016 or sold after 21 May 2017.<ref name="UK-vote">{{cite news|title=MPs pass legislation to introduce standardised cigarette packaging|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/mar/11/mps-pass-legislation-introduce-standardised-cigarette-packaging|date=11 March 2015|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=''The Guardian''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UK Government Legislation: The Standardised Packaging of Tobacco Products Regulations 2015|url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2015/829/contents/made|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref>
The UK regulations forbid "logos or promotional images … inserts … discounts … offers … information about nicotine, tar or carbon monoxide … lifestyle or environmental benefits [and] mentions or depictions of taste, smell or the absence thereof", while mandating "drab dark brown coloured packaging", specific package shapes and a specific font (Helvetica 14-point) for brand names.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK Government: Guidance: Packaging of tobacco products|accessdate=29 October 2018|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/packaging-of-tobacco-products}}</ref> The UK is also bound by the EU's Tobacco Products Directive (2014) which included a requirement for combined health warnings (picture, text and information on how to stop) covering 65 per cent of both the front and back of packaging.<ref name=EU2014 />

{{Unreferenced|date=January 2008}} '''Design standards''', '''reference standards''' and '''performance standards''' are familiar throughout business and industry, virtually for anything that is definable. [[Sustainable design]], taken as reducing our impact on the earth and making things better at the same time, is in the process of becoming defined. There are also lots of well organized specific methodologies that are used by different communities of people for different purposes.
== Design standards == One of the better known is the [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] (LEED) green building rating system, which uses a diverse group of hard measures of environmental quality and impacts to define a holistic approach to sustainable building and assign ratings to individual projects.
Sustainable design is really just a more determined effort to consider the whole range of impacts on our environment in making any decision. A more complete design guide, guided more by whole project impact measures, is the model offered by the U.S. cooperating agencies in the [http://www.wbdg.org/ "Whole Building Design Guide"].
Green construction codes and standards are beginning to emerge on the national code stage. The standards go beyond energy standards such as [[ASHRAE 90.1]] and the [[International Energy Conservation Code]] (IECC) to cover additional areas such as site sustainability, [[water efficiency]], indoor [[environmental quality]] and materials and resources. The first is [[ASHRAE 189.1]], Standard for the Design of High-Performance, Green Buildings Except Low-Rise Residential Buildings, published by ASHRAE in January 2010 in conjunction with the [[U.S. Green Building Council]] and the [[Illuminating Engineering Society]]. Standard 189.1 provides criteria by which a building can be judged as “green,” written in model code language that jurisdictions can use to develop a green building construction code.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
Several organizations have developed their own ways of setting goals for energy reductions, such as [[Architecture 2030]] and for qualifying performance toward them such as [[Cradle to Cradle Design|Cradle to Cradle]].
== Design methods == Developing real methods for how to discover the design opportunities that would allow you to meet or exceed the standards was one of the objectives of the environmental design movement in architectural schools in the 1960s and '70s, but though some of the issues introduced then are still an important part of the process, not much actually changed about the methods of design. Now with the combination of many more interactive tools and much higher stakes in the outcome, and long gestating rethinking about natural systems in general, a dramatic new revolution in methodology seems inevitable.
BIM (building information modeling) allows designers to work with many remote consultants on the same data file that represents all the decisions being made by the team. That same file is available to the [[climate and energy]] and environmental impact analysis and cost analysis tools and consultants, ... and of course to the prospective contractors and the regulators. Along with this new integrated access to the model there in needed a new way to integrate the conversation of so many people, each with some interest in reviewing each other's comments on the progress with the central design model. That is likely to involve development of wiki tools for the process. One such very early impliementation of a Wiki SD tool called [https://web.archive.org/web/20081007000010/http://www.connection.metadot.net/ "4Dsustainability"] organizes the project design evolution around the general learning process of '''how you define the problem''' by exploring its environment, and following that through the project.
The main difference between sustainable design methods and conventional design is incorporating the entire environment of the project's stakeholders on the design team, essentially, and that calls for new ways to explore connections and for more people and perspectives to be taken into account. Other methods that recognize this requirement are the [http://www.aia.org/liv_sdat "AIA SDAT"] (sustainable design assessment team) program and the [http://www.scenariosforsustainability.org/index.php "Scenarios for sustainability"] process design tools.

It features three sections: * DesignTAXI: a [[professional network]] for creative professionals, in association with design businesses, institutions, organizations and individuals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icsid.org/media/IDMN/member_list401.htm |title=DesignTAXI |accessdate=2012-04-25 |publisher=[[International Council of Societies of Industrial Design]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609123344/http://www.icsid.org/media/IDMN/member_list401.htm |archivedate=2012-06-09 |df= }}</ref> * The Bazaar: an [[online marketplace]] for creatives to sell their artworks.<ref>[http://bza.co/ The Bazaar]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/the-creative-bazaar |title=The Creative Bazaar |accessdate=2012-04-25|publisher=[[CrunchBase]]}}</ref> * The Creative Finder: a [[trade directory|global directory]] of professional creatives such as [[illustrator]]s, [[photographer]]s, [[designer]]s, and [[art director]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techinasia.com/tag/designtaxi/ |title=DesignTAXI |accessdate=2012-04-25 |publisher=TechInAsia}}</ref><ref>[http://thecreativefinder.com The Creative Finder]</ref>
TAXI also publishes articles at the website of [[Asian Correspondent]].<ref name="corres"/>
In May 2012, TAXI received a mention in [[Forbes]]'s '[https://www.forbes.com/sites/haydnshaughnessy/2012/05/05/the-top-five-sites-for-keeping-up-with-creativity-and-design/ The Top Five Sites for Keeping Up With Creativity and Design]'.
In July 2012, TAXI was featured in [[TIME]]'s '[http://techland.time.com/2012/03/21/the-140-best-twitter-feeds-of-2012/slide/taxi/#taxi The 140 Best Twitter Feeds Of 2012]'.
[[BBC]] names DesignTAXI as "[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/laurenlaverne/posts/TECH-KNOW-HOW-14-May-10 Website of the Week]" in May 2013.
In March 2013, DesignTAXI teams up with UNIQLO, one of the world's largest fashion retailers, to release [http://uniqlo.com/us/store/lifewear/item/076587001 co-branded t-shirts] worldwide. The T-shirts were later sold out online.
